options.D: It adds details, estimates, and order as per product Owner prioritization to Product Backlog items
options.E: The Product Owner may delegate this responsibility to others but he/she still remains accountable
options.F: It provides a formal description of the state of the Increment when it meets the quality measures required for the product

answers: It is an ongoing process and It adds details, estimates, and order as per product Owner prioritization to Product Backlog items and The Product Owner may delegate this responsibility to others but he/she still remains accountable

question: What are the important characteristics of a good Product Backlog item which can be considered as "Ready" for Sprint Planning?

options.A: Product Backlog items which are sufficiently refined & clearly expressed
options.B: Product Backlog item which can be developed within one Sprint even if tested in another Sprint
options.C: Product Backlog item which will be finished as per Definition of Done within one Sprint
options.D: Product Backlog items which are at or towards the bottom of the Product Backlog
options.E: Product Backlog item which is at the top of the  Product Backlog

answers: Product Backlog items which are sufficiently refined & clearly expressed and Product Backlog item which will be finished as per Definition of Done within one Sprint and Product Backlog item which is at the top of the  Product Backlog
explanation:
The Product Backlog is an emergent, ordered list of what is needed to improve the product. It is the single source of work undertaken by the Scrum Team.

Product Backlog items that will occupy developers for the upcoming Sprint are sufficiently refined so that any one item can reasonably be "Done" within the Sprint time-box. Product Backlog items that can be "Done" by developers within one Sprint are deemed "Ready" for selection in a Sprint Planning.



Higher ordered Product Backlog items are usually clearer and more detailed than lower ordered ones. More precise estimates are made based on the greater clarity and increased detail; the lower the order, the less detail.



Rest two options are incorrect as Product Backlog items that are at or towards the bottom of the Product Backlog are not clear enough to pick up in a sprint. Development & testing of the product is considered in the same sprint as the team has to deliver a working & usable increment which complies with Definition of Done. Without testing, the team can't consider an increment as done.

question: Which statement best describes a Product Owner's responsibility?

options.A: Keep stakeholders from distracting the Developers
options.B: Optimizing the value of the work the Scrum Team does
options.C: Managing the project and ensuring that the work meets the commitments to the stakeholders
options.D: Directing the Developers

answers: Optimizing the value of the work the Scrum Team does
explanation: The Product Owner is accountable for maximizing the value of the product and the work of the Scrum Team.

question: When many Scrum Teams are working on a single product, what best describes the Definition of Done?

options.B: Each Scrum Team uses its own, but must make their definition clear to all other teams so the differences are known
options.C: All Scrum Teams must have a Definition of Done that makes their combined Increment valuable and useful

answers: All Scrum Teams must have a Definition of Done that makes their combined Increment valuable and useful
explanation: The Increment must be valuable and useful. This means that when many Scrum Teams are working on a single product, they are expected to adhere to a single Definition of Done for the Increment.

question: The Developers should not be interrupted during the Sprint and the Sprint Goal should remain intact. These are conditions that foster creativity, quality and productivity. Which one of the following answers is FALSE?

options.A: The Developers may work with the Product Owner to remove or add work if it finds it has more or less capacity than it expected
options.B: As a decomposition of the selected Product Backlog items, the Sprint Backlog changes and may grow as the work emerges
options.C: The Sprint Backlog is fully formulated in the Sprint  Planning event and does not change during the Sprint
options.D: The Product Owner can help clarify or optimize the Sprint when asked by the Developers

answers: The Sprint Backlog is fully formulated in the Sprint  Planning event and does not change during the Sprint
explanation: The Sprint Backlog makes visible all of the work that the Developers identify as necessary to meet the Sprint Goal. The Developers modify the Sprint Backlog throughout the Sprint, and the Sprint Backlog emerges during the Sprint.

question: When does a Developer become the sole owner of an item or task on the Sprint Backlog?

options.A: Whenever a team member can accommodate more work
options.C: At the Sprint Planning event
options.D: Never. All Sprint Backlog items are “owned” by the Developers on the Scrum Team

answers: Never. All Sprint Backlog items are “owned” by the Developers on the Scrum Team
explanation: The entire Scrum Team is accountable for creating a valuable, useful Increment every Sprint, and the set of Product Backlog items selected for the Sprint are collectively owned by the Developers. No individual Developer can claim ownership over an item as this would block communication and collaboration. The Sprint Backlog is updated by the Developers throughout the Sprint as more is learned.

question: A Scrum Team consists of the following:

options.C: Users
options.D: Scrum Master
options.E: Product Owner

answers: Developers and Scrum Master and Product Owner
explanation: The Scrum Team consists of one Scrum Master, one Product Owner. and Developers.

question: Who should know the most about the progress toward a business objective or a release, and be able to explain the alternatives most clearly?

options.C: The Scrum Master
options.D: The Project Manager

answers: The Product Owner
explanation: The Product Owner is the sole person responsible for ordering the Product Backlog. Their responsibilities include making the Product Backlog visible, transparent, and clear to all.

question: Which of the following statements best describes transparency?

options.A: The process should be visible, and understood by key stakeholders
options.B: Significant aspects of the process must be visible to those responsible for the outcome
options.C: The whole process should be visible to stakeholders
options.D: The whole process should be visible to everyone

answers: Significant aspects of the process must be visible to those responsible for the outcome
explanation: Significant aspects means not all the details. Process means the way we work. Those responsible for the outcome means not all people in the world.

question: True or False. Velocity of Scrum Teams should be normalized, so that management can measure and compare their performance.
answers: No
explanation: Progress measurements are done internally, not by external managers. Also, comparing the velocity dependent on estimates of two different teams is never reliable, and it's not productive even if it were reliable. Different Scrum Teams can point differently.

question: How does the Product Owner determine the number of items for the Sprint Backlog?

options.C: In a way that maximizes the value of the Increment
options.D: Based on a combination of velocity and team capacity

answers: They don’t do it
explanation: It's only up to the self-managing Developers to decide how many items they will select for the Sprint Backlog.

question: Which of the following are pillars of Scrum?

options.C: Adaptation
options.D: Transparency
options.E: Inspection

answers: Adaptation and Transparency and Inspection
explanation: Pillars are transparency, inspection, and adaptation. Make sure you're not confusing these pillars with the Scrum values (commitment, courage, focus, openness, and respect).

question: Which of the following is the least productive way for the Scrum Master to improve the Developers' communications with the Product Owner?

options.A: Teach them how to effectively communicate
options.C: Suggest effective communication tools and techniques to the Product Owner
options.D: Act as a go-between for them

answers: Act as a go-between for them
explanation: Acting as a proxy doesn't work at all. Teaching and monitoring the communication is the right way to fix the problem. Make sure you have noticed the word "least".

question: True or False. The whole Sprint Backlog is defined in the Sprint Planning meeting.
answers: No
explanation: There are two elements in the Sprint Backlog: items selected from the Product Backlog and tasks created by decomposing those items. Sprint Backlog items could change as more is learnt, so it could change from the Developers.

question: True or False. Sprint Review is an informal meeting.
answers: Yes
explanation: The Scrum Guide states the word "formal" in two different ways. First, all events are "formal opportunities" for inspecting and adapting, which basically means a serious opportunity. So, if the question is "... is a formal opportunity for...", it would be a correct statement. The second usage is "formal meeting", which means a meeting where people approve something and exchange signatures. In that sense, none of the events are formal meetings. In the Sprint Review meeting, for example, the goal is creating feedback and adapting, not contract negotiations and exchanging signatures. So, if the statement is "... is a formal meeting", then it would be an incorrect statement. The Scrum Guide states: "Events are used in Scrum to create regularity and to minimize the need for meetings not defined in Scrum."

question: True or False. It's required to use User Stories in Scrum.
answers: No
explanation: It's a good idea to use User Stories to form the Product Backlog items, but it's not mandatory in Scrum.

question: Which of the following statements best describes the Sprint Review event?

options.A: A demo at the end of the Sprint for everyone in the organization to see the Increment
options.B: It’s a controlling mechanism for evaluating the work of Developers
options.C: It’s a celebration at the end of the Sprint to appreciate the work of Developers
options.D: An inspection of the Increment to collect feedback and see what to do in the next Sprint

answers: An inspection of the Increment to collect feedback and see what to do in the next Sprint
explanation: As stated in the Scrum Guide the purpose of the Sprint Review is to inspect the outcome of the Sprint and determine future adaptations. The Scrum Team presents the results of their work to key stakeholders and progress toward the Product Goal is discussed.

question: True or False. The Scrum Master could never order the Product Backlog items.
answers: No
explanation: The Product Owner may order the Product Backlog or may delegate the responsibility to others. Regardless, the Product Owner remains accountable.

question: True or False. A Scrum Team's velocity was 250 at the end of the 6th Sprint. It became 275 at the end of the 8th Sprint. Therefore, they are creating more value now compared to before.
answers: No
explanation: There's no direct relationship between velocity and value, maybe they're working faster on less valuable items, in which case, velocity will be higher, but value may be the same, higher, or lower. Many people consider velocity as the most important criterion, but that's not true -- they should rather be focused on value, Sprint Goal, and Product Goal.

question: Which of the following are required by Scrum?

options.C: User Stories
options.D: Scrum Events
options.E: Test-Driven Development

answers: Having timeboxed events and Scrum Events and Definition of Done
explanation: There are no Definition of Ready, TDD or User Stories in Scrum, they can be used, but they are not mandatory.

question: True or False. Each Increment must be released.
answers: No
explanation: Each Increment must be potentially releasable, but you don't have to release them.

question: True or False. The Scrum Team should have a Team Leader to improve communications and collaboration.
answers: No
explanation: It's not allowed to introduce new accountabilities or titles such as "Team Leader" in Scrum.

question: True or False. Adding new Developers to the team may cause a short-term decrease in productivity.
answers: Yes
explanation: When more Developers are added to the team, there's usually a short-term decrease in productivity because other members have to spend time and effort familiarizing the new members with the development environment of the project. After a while, the existence of new members may increase productivity, but even if it does, it's usually not a linear increase because, for example, having more people increases communication channels, which consumes some of the capacity.

question: Harry is a Scrum Master of a new Scrum Team with six Developers. He is trying to make sure that all the accountabilities are understood by the Scrum Team. Which of the following statements are correct about the Developers? (Select the best two answers)

options.A: They prioritize tasks in the Sprint Backlog
options.B: They participate in the Daily Serum meeting
options.C: Thay are responsible for engaging the stakeholders
options.D: They prioritize the Product Backlog items
options.E: They cause the removal of impediments

answers: They prioritize tasks in the Sprint Backlog and They participate in the Daily Serum meeting
explanation: The Product Owner is responsible for engaging the stakeholders. Developers are responsible for the Sprint Backlog and they must participate in Daily Scrum, others can attend as listeners. Removing impediments happens from everyone not only the Developers and they are all coached from the Scrum Master on how to do it. The Product Owner is the one who orders the items in the Product Backlog.

question: True or False. All teams should be cross-functional in scaled Scrum.
answers: Yes
explanation: It's one of the basic concepts in Scrum to have cross-functional, self-managing teams.

question: Three Scrum Teams are currently building a single product and pulling work from the same Product Backlog. All three teams have identified that they will need Dmytro, a database specialist, to work full time in their team for the next several Sprints. What should Steven, the Scrum Master, do to solve this potential problem?

options.A: Ask Dmytro to work with the HR department to recruit and hire additional database specialists. In the meantime, have the Product Owner move items that do not depend on Dmytro to the top of the Product Backlog
options.B: Coach the Scrum Teams to self-manage this issue and help them implement their preferred solution
options.C: Assign Dmytro to the team with the most urgent tasks first and then move him to the next team and so on until the required support is completed
options.D: Manage the items in the Sprint Backlogs so that Dmytro can be utilized evenly for each team

answers: Coach the Scrum Teams to self-manage this issue and help them implement their preferred solution
explanation: If requested, the Scrum Master can even facilitate conversations through open ended questions in order to help the team members make the best possible decisions according to what is known at the time. He/she does not approve or reject team decisions but ensures the team stays within the boundaries of the Scrum framework.

question: Who's responsible for quality?

options.C: Testers

answers: Developers
explanation: There are no Testers or Team Leaders in Scrum. There are only Developers, because we don't have extra accountabilities and titles in Scrum. However, there can be Developers who are experts in testing. Remember that everyone is called a Developer.

question: At the end of the Sprint, all items are done except for one that is almost done. What should be done with this item?

options.A: Put it in the next Sprint Backlog
options.B: The Sprint will be extended until we complete the item
options.C: It can be added to the Increment if the user acceptance tests are done
options.D: Move it back to the Product Backlog
options.E: It should not be included in the Increment

answers: Move it back to the Product Backlog and It should not be included in the Increment
explanation: It shouldn't be moved to the next Sprint Backlog. It has to go to the Product Backlog and let the Product Owner decide what is going to happen. If the item is still at the top, it will be selected in the next Sprint Planning meeting. The Increment contains only items that meet the DoD. Sprints are timeboxed, meaning that we don't extend their duration.

question: Which of the following statements are misleading about non-functional requirements? (Select the best three answers)

options.A: Some of them can be added to the Definition of Done
options.B: They will be in the Sprint Backlog, but not the Product Backlog
options.C: They will be reflected in the Sprint Goal
options.D: Scrum is all about functional requirements
options.E: They should be incorporated into every Increment
options.F: Some of them can be added to the Product Backlog or as per Acceptance Criteria of Product Backlog items

answers: They will be in the Sprint Backlog, but not the Product Backlog and They will be reflected in the Sprint Goal and Scrum is all about functional requirements
explanation: Non-functional features are about the way functional features work, not about the goals for Sprints. All items in the Sprint Backlog come from the Product Backlog, except for process improvement items (if the team decides it) that are generated in Sprint Retrospectives. There are non-functional requirements like security, scalability, maintainability, performance.

question: Which of the following statements best describe the Product Backlog? (Select the best three answers)

options.A: It’s used to create the project plan
options.B: The Product Owner is accountable for it
options.C: It may change anytime, and it is never complete
options.D: It changes as we learn more about the project
options.E: Provides just enough information to enable the Developers to design the whole product

answers: The Product Owner is accountable for it and It may change anytime, and it is never complete and It changes as we learn more about the project
explanation: It describes everything that is needed in the product. There's no "project plan" in Scrum. Product Backlog is the closest thing to a project plan that we have in Scrum.

question: An organization has just hired you as a new Scrum Master to help them transform their teams from their current traditional process to Scrum. The teams are currently structured to specialize in a single function, which is also known as component teams where a team would only address a single layer (i.e. front-end, back-end, testing, etc.). You’ve introduced the concept of cross-functional teams where all the skills needed to produce business functionality, from end to end, are inside of a single team. What should you keep in mind when transitioning from siloed teams to cross-functional teams? (Select the best two answers)

options.A: It is easier to compare the performance between cross-functional teams in order to identify which teams to assign tasks to and which teams need additional coaching
options.B: Without feature teams, you cannot do Scrum. Postpone Scrum adoption until the teams are reorganized in feature teams
options.C: People from the different layers and components will need time to become accustomed to working and delivering unified functionality together as one Scrum Team thus productivity may suffer
options.D: Newly formed teams will need time to stabilize before reaching their peak performance. During the initial stages of forming, performance will suffer and productivity may be low, although even then delivery of business value is still likely to increase

answers: People from the different layers and components will need time to become accustomed to working and delivering unified functionality together as one Scrum Team thus productivity may suffer and Newly formed teams will need time to stabilize before reaching their peak performance. During the initial stages of forming, performance will suffer and productivity may be low, although even then delivery of business value is still likely to increase
explanation: Forming a team takes time, and members often go through recognizable stages as they change from being a group of individuals to a team with common goals. Forming, Storming, Norming, and Performing model describes these stages by Bruce Tuckman. When you understand it, you can help your new team become effective more quickly.

question: What do we do with Done items when the Sprint is canceled?

options.A: They should be moved back to the Product Backlog, and will be taken care of in future Sprints
options.B: They should be moved to the next Sprint Backlog
options.C: They will be reviewed, and if they are potentially releasable, the Product Owner typically accepts them

answers: They will be reviewed, and if they are potentially releasable, the Product Owner typically accepts them
explanation: They are Done, so we shouldn't move them back to the Product Backlog? Items in the Sprint Backlog come from the Product Backlog. So, if it's supposed to be done, we will move them back to the Product Backlog, and if they are still on the top of the Product Backlog, they will be picked for the next Sprint. However, this question is about items that are Done, and there's no reason to move them back.

question: According to Scrum Theory, how should a group of fifty Developers be divided into multiple teams?

options.A: Allow the team leads to divide and select teams
options.B: Understanding the product, the product vision and the Scrum framework, the group self-manages into teams
options.C: The teams will rotate members every Sprint to spread knowledge
options.D: Create a skills matrix, identify their levels, and years of experience to assign people to teams

answers: Understanding the product, the product vision and the Scrum framework, the group self-manages into teams
explanation: The Scrum Team needs to be self-managing. The Scrum Master should coach them when needed or requested.

question: Who owns the Product Backlog?

options.C: The Product Owner
options.D: The Serum Master

answers: The Product Owner
explanation: The Product Owner is accountable for it, as stated in the Scrum Guide: "The Product Owner is also accountable for effective Product Backlog management"

question: How do changes in the project environment impact the Product Backlog?

options.A: The Product Backlog should be kept high-level enough to tolerate such changes
options.B: It evolves to reflect the changes (Correct)
options.C: The old baselined Product Backlog would be saved, and a new one would be created for the rest of the project
options.D: There’s no effect on the Product Backlog

answers: It evolves to reflect the changes (Correct)
explanation: The Product Backlog is not baselined. New changes should be investigated and create new items that cover it and maybe also change some of the existing items. The Product Backlog has "just enough" details, but it's not so high-level that it can tolerate all changes.

question: Which of the following are feedback loops in Scrum?

options.C: Burn-down chart
options.D: Sprint Planning

answers: Sprint Review and Sprint Planning
explanation: Releases are also feedback loops, but release planning has feedback elements in it, however, none of these are formal events in Scrum. This is an optional concept, and may facilitate the generation of some types of feedback, but it's not a "feedback loop". Sprint Planning, Daily Scrum, Sprint Review, and Sprint Retrospective are "formal opportunities for inspecting and adapting", and are considered to be "feedback loops". Note that being a "formal opportunity" doesn't mean that any signatures will be exchanged in those events, nor anything else that may turn them into "gates". The main purpose is to enable adaptation.

question: Which statement is correct about the Product Backlog?

options.C: It has no details

answers: It has just enough details
explanation: Both Sprint Backlog and Product Backlog evolve during their lives, and the amount of information grows as time passes. So, at each point in time, they don't have as much detail as they will probably have in the future. On the other hand, we never add all the details there. For example, it's common to say that a User Story doesn't provide all the information, but is an excuse for the people involved in the project to have communications around a certain topic. The details are in those communications and are not completely captured in the backlog.

question: Which of the following statements is correct about the Developers?

options.B: They order the Product Backlog items
options.C: They participate in the Daily Scrum meeting
options.D: They are responsible for measuring the performance of the project
options.E: They decide when to release the product

answers: They participate in the Daily Scrum meeting
explanation: Releasing the product, measuring the performance of the project and ordering the Product Backlog are the Product Owner's responsibility. Developers must participate in Daily Scrum. Others can attend as listeners.

question: The Sprint Backlog makes visible all the work that the _____ identify/identifies as necessary to meet the Sprint Goal.

options.C: Product Owner
options.D: Developers

answers: The Sprint Backlog makes visible all the work that the Developers
explanation: Developers are accountable for the Sprint Backlog and Sprint Goal is their commitment.

question: What's the main reason for the Product Owner to be at the Daily Scrum?

options.B: To track changes to the Sprint Backlog
options.C: To tell Developers what to do
options.D: It’s not necessary for them to be in the meeting
options.E: To order the Sprint Backlog

answers: It’s not necessary for them to be in the meeting
explanation: Developers are self-managed and take care of their commitment.In general, Daily Scrum is for the Developers, which means that the Developers must participate. Others can attend as listeners. The Product Owner can attend if necessary to answer questions.

question: Which of those statements are misleading about Scrum?

options.A: Scrum is like traditional processes but with self-management to replace Project Managers
options.B: Scrum is a framework for developing and sustaining complex products
options.C: Scrum is a methodology where you can pick and choose which parts of Scrum you think will work for your environment
options.D: Scrum is based on empirical process control theory
options.E: Scrum is a framework that eliminates complexity
options.F: Each component of Scrum serves a specific purpose and is essential to your ability to use Scrum to develop complex products

answers: Scrum is like traditional processes but with self-management to replace Project Managers and Scrum is a methodology where you can pick and choose which parts of Scrum you think will work for your environment and Scrum is a framework that eliminates complexity
explanation: Scrum is meant to be implemented as prescribed in the Scrum Guide, the five Scrum Events are mandatory and each one has a specific purpose. Scrum does not eliminate the complexity that is inherent in delivering a product in today’s world, instead it offers a framework for dealing with complexity. By regularly delivering Increments of value teams gain the ability to inspect and rapidly adapt based on the feedback received. Project Managers are not simply replaced by self-managing teams. Scrum is a framework for optimizing decision making based on the knowledge and experience of the entire team.

question: When does a customer cancel a Sprint?

options.A: When the Sprint Goal becomes obsolete
options.B: The customer doesn’t have the authority to cancel the Sprint
options.C: When not enough information is available for the items in the Sprint Backlog
options.D: When not enough resources are available for the project

answers: The customer doesn’t have the authority to cancel the Sprint
explanation: The Product Owner has the authority to cancel the Sprint. The customer isn't allowed to do so.

question: How many members are there in a Scrum Team?

options.C: 5 to 12
options.D: 3 to 9
options.E: 2 to 8

answers: Typically 10 or fewer
explanation: The Scrum Team is small enough to remain nimble and large enough to complete significant work within a Sprint, typically 10 or fewer people. In general, we have found that smaller teams communicate better and are more productive.

question: An organization is using Scrum to build five new products. What would be the best options for the number of Product Owners the organization should have? (Select the best two answers)

options.A: There is one Product Owner responsible for all five products. In order to scale his/her accountability, he/she can delegate some of the individual Product Owner responsibilities to others within each product but would still remain accountable for the value of the work produced
options.B: Enough Product Owners to delegate as much work needed to maximize utilization of all Developers
options.C: There is one Product Owner responsible for all five products. This person is not allowed to delegate any of the Product Owner responsibilities as he/she is accountable for the success of each product
options.D: There is one Product Owner for each product. Each Product Owner may delegate, share and align work within their individual Product Backlog

answers: There is one Product Owner responsible for all five products. In order to scale his/her accountability, he/she can delegate some of the individual Product Owner responsibilities to others within each product but would still remain accountable for the value of the work produced and There is one Product Owner for each product. Each Product Owner may delegate, share and align work within their individual Product Backlog
explanation: The Product Owner is the sole person responsible for maximizing the value of the product through the ordering and management of the Product Backlog. This reduces complexity in communication and understanding who to go to when there are questions about the product. The Product Owner may delegate his/her responsibilities but still remains accountable for the outcome of those responsibilities.

question: In Scrum, how would budgeting and financial forecasting be performed? (Select the best two answers)

options.A: Budgeting is not necessary as the only funding necessary is the operational costs of the Scrum Teams
options.B: A single release may be funded with several Sprints where every Sprint is producing shippable Increments
options.C: Frequently inspect the outcomes of the delivered Sprint Increments to understand how much value is being produced per investment spent
options.D: Fixed budgets are not allowed in Scrum

answers: A single release may be funded with several Sprints where every Sprint is producing shippable Increments and Frequently inspect the outcomes of the delivered Sprint Increments to understand how much value is being produced per investment spent
explanation: The cost of developing, delivering, and sustaining products can impact how the flow of value is managed throughout the life of a product. Each Sprint is an opportunity to inspect the investment (financial, time, effort, etc.) against the returned value (customer satisfaction, revenue, etc.) of the work that has been delivered. The team can then decide on what it should do next to maximize the value of the investment.

question: What's the role of a Scrum Master during Sprint Retrospectives?

options.A: Participating as a Scrum Team member
options.B: Summarizing and report the results of the meeting to stakeholders
options.C: Capturing process improvement ideas for the next Sprint Backlog
options.D: They should not participate in this meeting

answers: Participating as a Scrum Team member
explanation: The whole Scrum Team participates in the Sprint Retrospective, and they work together to see how they can improve the way they work in the next Sprint.

question: True or False. The Scrum Master can also be the Product Owner.
answers: Yes
explanation: According to Scrum Guide, one person can have more than one accountabilities. It's not recommended, but it's not forbidden either. They don't forbid it because some of the small projects may need to use a few people to do multiple things. When doing that, the person must make sure that they are paying attention to all responsibilities that they have for each role, which is not easy.

question: Which of the following contribute the most to the Scrum value "focus"? (Select the best three answers)

options.C: Timeboxing
options.D: Sprint Review
options.E: Sprint Goal

answers: Product Goal and Timeboxing and Sprint Goal
explanation: Helps you focus on the outcome that is expected from the Sprint. Helps you focus on the most valuable aspects of items selected for the Sprint, rather than making those items fancies, because time is not unlimited. Scrum values are commitment, courage, focus, openness, and respect.

question: What's the role of a Project Management Office (PMO) in an organization that only uses Scrum for project delivery?

options.A: There’s no place for a PMO in such an organization
options.B: Manages portfolios and programs and facilitates the application
options.C: of techniques that complement Scrum
options.D: The PMO should manage and help Scrum Masters
options.E: The PMO should manage and help Product Owners

answers: Manages portfolios and programs and facilitates the application
explanation: There are limits to the self-management of the team, and the important thing is to have the power within the borders of the project. However, each project is run in a wider organization with multiple levels of management impacting the project, and it's not possible or even acceptable to reject that structure, as long as it doesn't block the internal self-management of the team and the fundamental adaptive approach of the project.

question: How many hours per day should a Developer work?

options.A: Depends on the Product Owners pressure from stakeholders
options.C: At least 6 ideal man-hours
options.D: As much as needed for realizing the Sprint Backlog items by the end of the Sprint
options.E: Normally, 40 hours a week

answers: At a constant pace
explanation: This is one of the Agile principles. The Sprint Backlog is just a rough estimate of what we can do. We will have a constant pace and deliver as much as we can, within the defined quality, and nothing bad happens if all items are not delivered.

question: What happens between two Sprints?

options.C: Nothing
options.D: Getting customer approval for the previous Increment

answers: Nothing
explanation: Sprints are happening continuously. Refactoring is done during the Sprints. Each Sprint starts immediately after the previous one, there's no space between the two.

question: Which of the following statements are misleading about the length of Sprints? (Select the best two answers)

options.A: Sprint length is set during Sprint Planning, and is long enough to develop all items in the Sprint Backlog
options.B: Sprint length is set during Sprint Planning, and is long enough for programming and testing all items, but not for integrating them
options.C: It’s preferred to have Sprints with the same length
options.D: The longer the Sprint the higher the risk
options.E: All Sprints must be one month or less

question: On average, items on the Product Backlog tend to be _______________

options.B: Larger than those on the Sprint Backlog
options.C: The same size as those on the Sprint Backlog

answers: On average, items on the Product Backlog tend to be Larger than those on the Sprint Backlog
explanation: Product Backlog has larger items that usually needs to be broken down into very small and clear items, because it's a form of upfront planning. Some of them may be very large. When you order the items, if they are on the top of the list, you have to make them clear, and make sure they can fit into one Sprint; therefore, you will break them down into smaller items.

question: True or False. The Product Owner is the main person responsible for engaging the stakeholders.
answers: Yes
explanation: Engagement of stakeholders is mostly about and around the Product Backlog items, and at least indirectly, about the value created in the project. That's why this is mainly the responsibility of the Product Owner to keep them engaged. Others may contribute as well like the Scrum Master may remove impediments related to engaging stakeholders and Developers may find ways to facilitate it. Nevertheless, the main person responsible for engaging stakeholders is the Product Owner.

question: True or False. It's up to the self-managing team to decide which Scrum artifacts are needed in the project.
answers: No
explanation: Self-management is not unlimited, the Scrum Team should follow the Scrum framework.

question: During Sprint Planning, the Definition of Done will help the Scrum Team forecast the amount of work, selected from the Product Backlog, deemed feasible to meet the "Done" by the end of the Sprint. Which two items best describe what "Done" means? (Select the best two answers)

options.A: All the work needed to prepare the Increment for Integration Testing
options.B: All the work completed within the current skills and expertise in the Scrum Team
options.C: Having an Increment of working software that is potentially releasable to the end users
options.D: All the work performed as defined in the Definition of Done
options.E: All the work needed to prepare the Increment for User Acceptance Testing

answers: Having an Increment of working software that is potentially releasable to the end users and All the work performed as defined in the Definition of Done
explanation: When a Product Backlog item or an Increment is described as ‘Done’, everyone must understand what ‘Done’ means. Although this may vary significantly per Scrum Team, members must have a shared understanding of what it means for work to be complete, to ensure transparency. question: What's the normal timeboxed duration of Sprint Review when there are 6 Developers in the team and Sprints are two weeks long?

question: The timebox of this Scrum Event should be no more than four hours.

options.C: Sprint Retrospective

question: Which of the following elements are attributes of Product Backlog items?

options.C: Estimate
options.D: Order

answers: Description and Estimate and Order
explanation: Product Backlog refinement is the act of breaking down and further defining Product Backlog items into smaller more precise items. This is an ongoing activity to add details, such as a description, order, and size. Attributes often vary with the domain of work.

question: Which of the following is least likely to be used by a Scrum Team?

options.C: Wiki, online forum
options.D: Large screen, Planning Poker cards

explanation: Note the word "least" in the question. WBS and Gantt Chart are mainly used in planning predictive (plan-based) projects rather than adaptive (Agile) ones.

question: Which of the following statements show the result of changing Scrum terminology while implementing it in the organization? (Select the best three answers)

options.A: They will get better results adopting Scrum this way
options.B: The change might not be obvious to everyone, and therefore very little change actually happens
options.C: The change might not be obvious to everyone! and some benefits may be lost
options.D: It’s necessary to tailor Scrum to suit the project
options.E: Management may feel less enthusiastic about the change

answers: The change might not be obvious to everyone, and therefore very little change actually happens and The change might not be obvious to everyone! and some benefits may be lost and Management may feel less enthusiastic about the change
explanation: Scrum is a simple framework rather than a comprehensive methodology, and it contains only the necessary minimums that you need in every project. So, instead of normal tailoring (adjusting the existing elements), you will follow everything that is described in Scrum, and suit it to your project by the practices and techniques that you add; e.g. Planning Poker, Pair-Programming, and Test-Driven Development. question: Which of the following statements best describe Sprint Planning? (Select the best two answers)

options.E: What went wrong in the last Sprint and what to do about it?

answers: How are we going to do what we have decided to do in the Sprint? and What are we going to do during the Sprint?
explanation: What went wrong in the last Sprint would be discussed in the previous Sprint Retrospective. Sprint Planning has to do with the work for the next Sprint and has to cover three topics, Why is this Sprint valuable? What can be Done this Sprint? and How will the chosen work get done?

question: Who can attend the Daily Scrum meeting?

question: True or False. The Scrum Master should ask each Developer to answer the three standard questions at the Daily Scrum.

question: True or False. Vicky is a Scrum Master of a 13-member Scrum Team (including her). Because of the team size it is mandatory to divide the Scrum Team.

As stated in the Scrum Guide the Scrum Team is small enough to remain nimble and large enough to complete significant work within a Sprint, typically 10 or fewer people.

question: What would be two boundaries, defined in Scrum, that give guidance for teams to effectively self-manage? (Select the best two answers)

options.A: Clearly defined functional teams within the Scrum Team to define handoff phases during development
options.B: Timeboxing the events in Scrum to allow for regular inspection and adaptation creating opportunities to adjust course in any given path

answers: Timeboxing the events in Scrum to allow for regular inspection and adaptation creating opportunities to adjust course in any given path and Creating an integrated and potentially shippable Increment by the end of each Sprint

question: The Product Owner is not collaborating with the Developers during the Sprint. Which of the following actions would you choose as the Scrum Master? (Select the best two answers)

answers: Coach the Product Owner to understand why collaboration is important in Scrum and how it can affect the value of the product and Bring up the issue in the next Sprint Retrospective

Talking to the functional manager of the Product Owner is not right, it's best to resolve issues internally. There's no proxy Product Owner in Scrum.

question: According to the values of Scrum, which is the best way to create teams of developers?

options.A: Work with the leadership team to allocate members according to skills, seniority and experience to ensure that all Scrum Teams are balanced fairly

question: Which of the following statements best explain the benefits of having tests in the Definition of Done? (Select the best two answers)

options.C: Increases transparency of the Increments

answers: Increments would be closer to potentially releasable and Increases transparency of the Increments
explanation: You can't release it unless you've tested the output and are sure it won't create problems in production, so if you add tests in the DoD, you will prevent issues from happening and transparency of the quality of the Increment.

question: Which of the following are timeboxed?

options.C: Sprint Retrospective
options.D: Sprint Review

answers: Sprint and Sprint Retrospective and Sprint Review
explanation: There's no release Retrospective event in Scrum. It's done frequently, and it's not timeboxed. Testing is done continuously. The Scrum Events are timeboxed.

question: Which of the following statements best describes the Scrum Pillar of Adaptation.

options.B: If any aspects of a process deviate outside acceptable limits or if the resulting product is unacceptable, the process being applied or the materials being produced must be adjusted

answers: If any aspects of a process deviate outside acceptable limits or if the resulting product is unacceptable, the process being applied or the materials being produced must be adjusted

question: True or False. The Product Owner and Scrum Master are not allowed to be part of the Developers.

question: Why are Daily Scrums held at the same time and same place?

question: Which of the following is not required by Scrum?

explanation: TDD is not required, the rest are mandatory in Scrum.

question: True or False. Cross-functional teams are optimized in a technical layer of a system.

question: What is the main reason for the Scrum Master to be at the Daily Scrum?

question: Which of the following actions may a Scrum Master take in starting up a project?

answers: They can get help from the Product Owner to adjust the Sprint Backlog
explanation: They should be open and speak to the Product Owner about it. They can negotiate with the Product Owner about the items. The Sprint is cancelled when the Sprint Goal becomes obsolete, not when we see that we can't deliver all items. Nothing bad happens if you don't deliver everything.

question: Which of the following can be considered a real output of a Sprint?

options.A: A document that describes the architecture of the software and can be used by the Developers in the rest of the project
options.B: A set of tests designed to be used in the next Sprint
options.C: An Increment of software with minor known bugs in it
options.D: A potentially releasable piece of software

answers: A potentially releasable piece of software
explanation: If we are aware of a bug, we should fix it before calling it "Done". Increment is a piece of working software that meets the Definition of Done.

question: Who is responsible for engaging stakeholders?

options.C: The Developers
options.D: The Scrum Master

answers: The Product Owner
explanation: Engagement of stakeholders is mostly about and around the Product Backlog items. The Product Owner is responsible for the Product Backlog, so she/he has to create items that reflect maximum value. That's why this is mainly the responsibility of the Product Owner to keep them engaged. The rest of them can help in different ways, but it is mainly the Product Owner.

question: You are the Scrum Master for a Scrum Team. One of the Developers approaches you and tells you that during the Sprint they don't complete full regression testing for all of the selected Product Backlog Items. Regression testing is part of the agreed Definition of Done. The Developers have discussed with the Product Owner and decided to change the Definition of Done (DoD) to remove regression testing. Which actions are most inappropriate? (Select the best two answers)

options.A: Ask the team coaching questions. Eg. ask the Developers and the Product Owner what problem they will be solving by removing regression testing from the Definition of Done. Will this raise transparency or improve the quality of the Increment?
options.B: Agree with altering the Definition of Done as the Developers and Product Owner agree. We need to make our Scrum Team self-managing
options.C: Disagree with the Developers decision and tell them that having a better Definition of Done is important for the quality of the product, and they should follow it
options.D: Ask the team some powerful questions. Eg. ask the Developers and Product Owner, “Will removing regression testing from the Definition of Done allow the team to produce potentially releasable Increments at the end of every Sprint?

answers: Agree with altering the Definition of Done as the Developers and Product Owner agree. We need to make our Scrum Team self-managing and Disagree with the Developers decision and tell them that having a better Definition of Done is important for the quality of the product, and they should follow it
explanation: The Scrum Master serves the Scrum Team in several ways, including coaching the team members in self-management and cross-functionality. Helping the Scrum Team focus on creating high-value Increments that meet the Definition of Done. Causing the removal of impediments to the Scrum Team’s progress. Ensuring that all Scrum events take place and are positive, productive, and kept within the timebox.

question: True or False. When multiple teams are working on the same product, their Sprints should start and end at the same date.
answers: No
explanation: It's not mandatory in the Scrum Guide to start and end the Sprints at the same time. That makes it much more difficult to manage the whole project. However It's not mandatory for many teams to be aligned on this, because you may need it in certain cases: maybe some teams are working on parts of the project that need longer Sprints, while others need shorter ones.

question: Which of the following statements could be outputs of the Sprint Planning meeting? (Select the best two answers)

options.A: Items selected from the Product Backlog
options.B: Order of items in the Product Backlog
options.C: Estimations for the sizes of items
options.D: Tasks
options.E: Resource assignment

answers: Items selected from the Product Backlog and Tasks
explanation: Sprint Planning is an event that answers three questions: "Why is this Sprint valuable?", "What can be Done this Sprint?" and "How will the chosen work get done?" Tasks and Items from Product Backlog are the only options that can be obtained from these questions of the Sprint Planning event.

question: Which of the following statements describe something that may be done in the Sprint Retrospective meeting? (Select the best three answers)

options.B: Discuss techniques used to facilitate the Sprint Retrospective meeting
options.C: Discuss the composition of the team
options.D: Refining the Product Backlog
options.E: Discuss the Product Backlog items for the next Sprint
options.F: Discuss tools used to communicate with remote team members

answers: Discuss techniques used to facilitate the Sprint Retrospective meeting and Discuss the composition of the team and Discuss tools used to communicate with remote team members
explanation: Calculate Velocity is usually something that you do before Sprint Review meetings. Refinement is done continuously during the Sprint. Product Backlog items for the next Sprint is not something to discuss during Sprint Retrospectives, Sprint Review could be a better place. Sprint Retrospective is about the way we work. It's about the things that affect the product, but we don't discuss the product directly. It's about the context, not the content.

question: What would likely happen if management only changed the organization’s current terminology to fit Scrum without the proper understanding and support of Scrum as defined in the Scrum Guide?

options.A: The organization may not realize the real benefits of Scrum as there would be no real change on the way the teams work
options.B: Organizations may feel less stressed as the behaviors would remain familiar to management
options.C: None of the answers apply
options.D: Very little change will happen as the vocabulary in Scrum is specifically defined for implementing Serum
options.E: All answers apply

answers: All answers apply
explanation: The defined terminology in Scrum was selected, designed, and defined specifically for supporting the Scrum Framework. Understanding the differences between traditional methods and the Scrum Framework will help move teams in the right direction in Scrum adoption.

question: Which of the following are Scrum Pillars?

options.C: Creativity
options.D: Adaptation
options.E: Transparency

answers: Inspection and Adaptation and Transparency
explanation: Pillars are transparency, inspection, and adaptation. Make sure you're not confusing these pillars with the Scrum values commitment, courage, focus, openness and respect.

question: If a Scrum Team has one week Sprints, when should we have a potentially releasable product?

options.B: When the Product Owner finds it necessary
options.C: Every 3 to 5 Sprints
options.D: After each Hardening Sprint

answers: Often during the Sprint
explanation: There are no hardening Sprints. There should be at least one Increment at the end of each Sprint that is potentially releasable. The shorter the feedback loop the better.

question: Which of the following statements are correct when four teams are working on a product? (Select the best three answers)

options.A: There can be multiple Scrum Masters
options.B: There can be multiple Product Owners
options.C: There is only one Product Backlog
options.D: There can be multiple Product Backlogs
options.E: There are multiple Sprint Backlogs each Sprint
options.F: There is only one Sprint Backlog each Sprint

answers: There can be multiple Scrum Masters and There is only one Product Backlog and There are multiple Sprint Backlogs each Sprint
explanation: Product Owners is one person not a committee and he/she owns one single Product Backlog. Each team has separate Sprint Backlog and Scrum Events and the Product Owner assists each one of them.

question: Who is responsible for explaining the Product Backlog items?

options.C: Product Owner
options.D: The Developers are self-managed and have to talk to anyone necessary, and find out the meanings of items
options.E: User representatives

answers: Product Owner
explanation: It's one of the responsibilities of the Product Owner to explain what each item in the Product Backlog means and make sure that everyone has the right understanding. This is done when the item is first defined, and also during the Sprint and/or refinement when the Developers are working on the item and may have doubts.

question: True or False. Developers should be cross-functional
answers: No
explanation: The whole Scrum Team is cross-functional, meaning the members have all the skills necessary to create value each Sprint, as stated in the Scrum Guide (not just the Developers).

question: True or False. Time can be allocated between two Sprints for integration.
answers: No
explanation: Each Sprint starts immediately after the previous one. There's nothing between the two Sprints. It should be continuous integration. Something is not Done unless it's integrated and it is released in the Sprint. There are no Integration Sprints.

question: Which statement is correct about the Sprint Backlog?

options.C: It has all the details

answers: It has just enough details
explanation: Both Sprint Backlog and Product Backlog evolve more information as time passes, so they have just enough information to move to the next stage e.g. during refinement, Sprint Planning etc.

question: The Developers have realized that one of the planned tasks in the Sprint Backlog is not needed anymore. What should they do?

options.A: Inform the Product Owner, so that he/she can cancel the Sprint
options.B: Remove it if it’s OK with the Product Owner
options.C: Keep it, but inform the Product Owner
options.D: Ask the Product Owner to remove it

answers: Remove it if it’s OK with the Product Owner
explanation: The Developers own the Sprint Backlog, and they make changes to it. They don't even have to ask the Product Owner, if it's about a non-functional requirement. Product Owner's consultation is needed when it's about functions/features. Sprints are cancelled when the Sprint Goal becomes obsolete, it's not the case here.

question: Which of the following is not a feedback loop in Scrum?

options.C: None of the answers apply
options.D: Sprint Planning
options.E: Sprint Retrospective

answers: Product Backlog refinement
explanation: Sprint Planning, Daily Scrum, Sprint Review, and Sprint Retrospective are formal opportunities for inspecting and adapting, and are considered "feedback loops".

question: What's the role of a Product Owner during Sprint Retrospectives?

options.A: Summarizing and report the results of the meeting to stakeholders
options.B: Participating as a Scrum Team member
options.C: None of the answers apply
options.D: They should not participate in this meeting
options.E: Capturing requirements for the Product Backlog

answers: Participating as a Scrum Team member
explanation: The whole Scrum Team can participate in the Sprint Retrospective and they work together to see how they can improve the way they work in the next Sprint. There is no difference between PRoduct Owner, Developer or Scrum Master.

question: What should be the timebox of Sprint Retrospective when there are 6 Developers in the team and Sprints are two weeks long?

options.C: 8 hours
options.D: 1.5 hours

answers: 3 hours
explanation: The Sprint Retrospective is timeboxed to a maximum of three hours for a one-month Sprint. For shorter Sprints, the event is usually shorter. Note that the duration of events is not dependent on the number of Developers.

question: Who should know the least about the progress toward a business objective or a release, and be able to explain the alternatives most clearly?

options.C: The Product Owner
options.D: The Scrum Master

answers: The Project Manager and The Developers and The Scrum Master
explanation: The Product Owner is the sole person responsible for managing the Product Backlog, which includes that the Product Backlog is visible, transparent, and clear to all, and shows what the Scrum Team will work on next. Make sure you have noticed the word "least" in the question.

question: Which are two good approaches for the Developers to make non-functional requirements visible?

options.A: QA must run integration and regression tests before the end of the Sprint
options.B: Add them to the Product Backlog and keep the Product Owner informed of the estimated effort
options.C: Create one special Product Backlog only for these requirements
options.D: Add them to the acceptance criteria as part of the Definition of Done

answers: Add them to the Product Backlog and keep the Product Owner informed of the estimated effort and Add them to the acceptance criteria as part of the Definition of Done
explanation: Non-functional requirements should be visible to the Product Owner. The Product Owner is the sole person responsible for managing the Product Backlog but always can and must consider the feedback and opinion from other stakeholders including the Developers who can influence to add new items in Product Backlog.

question: Who tracks the remaining work of a current Sprint?

options.C: The Product Owner
options.D: Stakeholders
options.E: The Solution Architect

answers: The Developers
explanation: Developers should be able to self-manage their work, they own the Sprint Backlog.

question: Which of the following best describes Sprint Planning?

options.A: What to do and who will do it?
options.B: What can be done and how to do it?
options.C: What went wrong in the last Sprint and what to do about it?
options.D: Who will be in the team this Sprint?

answers: What can be done and how to do it?
explanation: Sprint Planning is about three topics: Why is this Sprint valuable?, What can be Done this Sprint? and How will the chosen work get done?

question: True or False. Having the team members and a complete Product Backlog are the only things needed to start the project.
answers: No
explanation: The Product Backlog is never complete. It's always evolving in adaptive methods.

question: True or False. All Developers should be cross-functional.
answers: No
explanation: The whole Scrum Team has to be cross-functional, not the individuals inside the team.

question: True or False. The Product Backlog only contains functional features.
answers: No
explanation: Product Backlog can also have non-functional features and the Product Owner is still accountable for them.

question: Which of the following is correct about the length of Sprints?

options.A: Sprint length is set during Sprint Planning, and is long enough for programming and testing all items, but not for integrating them
options.B: All Sprints must be one month or less
options.C: The length can change as part of self-managing Scrum Teams, depending on the DevOps Team
options.D: Sprint length is set during Sprint Planning, and is long enough to develop all items in the Sprint Backlog

answers: All Sprints must be one month or less
explanation: One month is the maximum timeboxed duration for Sprints in the Scrum Guide.

question: True or False. Besides the normal items that are about the features of the product, each Sprint Backlog can contain one item about improving the way Developers work.
answers: Yes
explanation: They can add an item if they think it's necessary but it's not mandatory. However if the team finds it useful they can add it, there is nothing in the Scrum Guide that prohibits this.

question: Which of the following statements are correct about Product Backlog refinement? (Select the best two answers)

options.A: It should be done right before Sprint Planning
options.B: It can be an ongoing process if Developers need more time to know more
options.C: It can be part of Retrospective
options.D: Multiple teams may participate in it
options.E: The Scrum Master should facilitate it
options.F: Normally, it doesn’t take more than 10% of the Product Owner’s time

answers: It can be an ongoing process if Developers need more time to know more and Multiple teams may participate in it
explanation: The Scrum Master facilitates as requested or required, not by default, but the Product Owner is more likely to facilitate this meeting, since he/she knows more about the Product Backlog items. As stated in the Scrum Guide "Product Backlog refinement is the act of breaking down and further defining Product Backlog items into smaller more precise items. This is an ongoing activity to add details, such as a description, order, and size."

question: True or False. When the team becomes mature enough in using Scrum, they won't need a Scrum Master anymore.
answers: No
explanation: A Scrum Master is always needed, maybe he will contribute less but he is still needed.

question: A Scrum project is supposed to have two releases one in the middle and the other at the end of the project. Which of the following statements is correct?

options.A: Increments are created for investigation and adaptation; they don’t have to be releasable
options.B: Having releasable Increments depends on the operations’ preference
options.C: Increments that are created before each release should be releasable
options.D: All Increments should be releasable

answers: All Increments should be releasable
explanation: All Increments must be potentially releasable to enable usable feedback, regardless of the actual releases we may have.

question: During the Sprint Review, one of the stakeholders announces that due to recent market changes, there is risk that funding might be reduced for the project. This triggers tensions to rise and arguments to break out between members. As a Scrum Master, what would be the best two actions to take? (Select the best two answers)

options.A: Inform everyone that the team needs to stay busy until the information is formally announced
options.B: Avoid getting involved as it is the Product Owner’s responsibility to manage stakeholder expectations
options.C: Defend the original budget and request the stakeholders to adhere to the original agreed funding for the product
options.D: Be objective and request for a short break for people to calm down
options.E: Encourage the stakeholders and Product Owner to focus on delivering the highest value items for the next Sprint

answers: Be objective and request for a short break for people to calm down and Encourage the stakeholders and Product Owner to focus on delivering the highest value items for the next Sprint
explanation: The Scrum Master is responsible for promoting and supporting Scrum by helping everyone embody the values of commitment, courage, focus, openness and respect.

question: True or False. It's allowed to have Team Leaders when many Developers are working on a complex project with multiple Scrum Teams.
answers: No
explanation: It's not allowed to introduce new accountabilities or titles such as "Team Leader" in Scrum.

question: True or False. Each Sprint Backlog may contain an item about improving the way we work.
answers: Yes
explanation: It is not mandatory in the Scrum, but if the Scrum Team finds it useful they can do it, it's not prohibited.

question: True or False. The Developers are responsible for composing the Definition of Ready.
answers: No
explanation: There is no official Definition of Ready in the Scrum Guide. However there is a part in the guide that mentions the meaning of a "ready" item, but not such a definition as Definition of Ready. The Scrum Guide states "Product Backlog items that can be Done by the Scrum Team within one Sprint are deemed ready for selection in a Sprint Planning event."

question: True or False. The first Sprint can start as soon as the Product Backlog is complete.
answers: No
explanation: The Product Backlog is never complete. It's always evolving in adaptive methods.

question: The customer goes to the Developers in the middle of a Sprint and asks them to add an important item to the Sprint Backlog. What should they do?

options.A: Refer the customer to the Product Owner
options.B: Add the item to the current Sprint Backlog
options.C: Replace one of the existing items in the Sprint Backlog with the new one
options.D: Reject the request

answers: Refer the customer to the Product Owner
explanation: The Product Owner is the only person responsible for the items and the order in which they are developed.

question: Which of the following is not correct about the Product Owner accountability?

options.B: Is responsible for maximizing the value of the product
options.C: Answers questions about the items in the Sprint Backlog
options.D: Explains the Product Backlog items

answers: Is cross-functional
explanation: The Product Owner explains the Product Backlog items The whole Scrum Team is cross-functional, not the Product Owner by herself/himself. The primary responsibility of the Product Owner is to maximize the value of the product that is developed. Make sure that you have noticed the word "not" in the question.

question: Which of the following limits work in progress?

options.C: Using Product Backlogs
options.D: Having Sprint Reviews

answers: Using timeboxes
explanation: When using timeboxes, you have a rather small and relatively clear scope for the timebox, and your goal is to complete as many items as possible. This limits the amount of work you can have in progress.

question: When is it time to integrate the code?

options.B: At the end of the project
options.C: Before each release
options.D: At the end of each Sprint

answers: Frequently, during the Sprint
explanation: You can't know if the code will work properly, unless you integrate it with the rest of the code. That's why we have continuous integration.

question: How would you know if Developers are cross-functional?

options.A: They can create releasable Increments each Sprint
options.B: They can do Test Driven Development if they decide to
options.C: They can do Pair-Programming if they decide to
options.D: Each Developer is expert in all technical layers of the system

answers: They can create releasable Increments each Sprint
explanation: Cross-functional Developers must have all skills needed to create a releasable Increments every Sprint. A cross-functional Scrum Team is one that has all types of expertise that is required to develop the product. Note that the whole Scrum Team should be cross-functional, not individual team members. e.g. in this scenario here we could assume that Product Owner and Scrum Master are Developers as well.

question: Which of the following is correct about the Scrum Team?

options.B: Is responsible for measuring the performance of the project
options.C: All answers apply
options.D: Is self-managed
options.E: None of the answers apply
options.F: Is responsible for maximizing the value of the product

answers: Is self-managed
explanation: The whole Scrum Team is self-managed, as stated in the Scrum Guide. The Product Owners measure the performance of the project to maximize the value of the product that is developed.

question: True or False. Inspection is a Scrum Value.
answers: No
explanation: Pillars are transparency, inspection, and adaptation. Make sure you're not mixing them with the Scrum Values commitment, courage, focus, openness, and respect.

question: Who can decide to add more work to the Sprint Backlog during the Sprint?

options.C: The Scrum Master
options.D: The Product Owner
options.E: The Scrum Team

answers: The Developers
explanation: After the Sprint Planning the items pulled from Product Backlog, they can’t change. However in the Sprint Backlog the broken down tasks created by the Developers to complete the work are always changing and adapting according to their practices, techniques, and knowledge.

question: What happens between a Sprint Retrospective and the next Sprint Planning meeting?

options.A: Getting customer approval for the previous Increment
options.B: A lot of events could happen, depending of what has been agreed from the Scrum Team, since they are self-managed
options.C: Nothing
options.D: Product Backlog refinement
options.E: Refactoring the previous Increment

explanation: Refinement is an ongoing process. Refactoring is done during the Sprints; we can't revisit the previous ones. Each Sprint starts immediately after the previous one, there's no space between the two.

question: Which of the following statements best describes good ways to address security concerns? (Select the best two answers)

options.A: Add them to the Product Backlog
options.B: Add them to the Definition of Done
options.C: Get help from responsible departments to ensure those concerns
options.D: Have special Sprints that ensure those concerns

answers: Add them to the Product Backlog and Add them to the Definition of Done
explanation: Add them in the Product Backlog if it's about the performance of an existing function. If it's something that applies to many items and determines the way functional features work it would be a good choice to add them in the Definition of Done. There are no "special" Sprints such as hardening Sprints or integration Sprints.

question: When does a Product Owner cancel a Sprint?

options.A: When not enough information is available for the items in the Sprint Backlog
options.B: When the Sprint Goal becomes obsolete
options.C: When there’s an unsolved technical dependency
options.D: When not enough resources are available for the project

answers: When the Sprint Goal becomes obsolete
explanation: As stated in the Scrum Guide "A Sprint could be cancelled if the Sprint Goal becomes obsolete. Only the Product Owner has the authority to cancel the Sprint."

question: What does a burn-down chart measure?

options.B: The amount of business value delivered to the customer
options.C: Work that is done based on the Definition of Done
options.D: Cost of the project across time

answers: Work remaining across time
explanation: A burndown chart is a graphic representation of how quickly the team is working through Sprint Backlog across time.

question: Which of the following are formal opportunities for inspecting and adapting? (Select the best two answers)

options.C: Sprint Retrospective
options.D: Product Backlog refinement

answers: Daily Scrum and Sprint Retrospective
explanation: Sprint Planning, Daily Scrum, Sprint Review, and Sprint Retrospective are formal opportunities for inspecting and adapting and considered "feedback loops".

question: The Product Owner is not getting well with the Developers. options.A: Check with each person’s functional manager to suggest to their employees that they should collaborate in a better way and if they don’t they might be removed from the team
options.B: Scrum Master’s accountability is to protect the Developers all the time. Ask for a project manager or another external instance to interfere and possibly temporarily take over from the Product Owner his job
options.C: None of the answers apply

options.E: Take everyone to a 1-day offsite event to relax, re-align and resolve the conflict

answers: Try to address why requirements change in the Sprint Retrospective. Ask the Developers and the Product Owner to talk about why and consider the impact of the changes on value. This will also make the team cohesive
explanation: Try to address why requirements change in the Sprint Retrospective. Ask the Developers and the Product Owner to talk about why and consider the impact of the changes on value. Coach the team to resolve these issues amongst themselves and facilitate if necessary.

question: Which of the following statements best describes the Scrum Pillar of Inspection.

options.A: The Scrum artifacts and the progress toward agreed goals must be inspected frequently and diligently to detect potentially undesirable variances or problems
options.B: If any aspects of a process deviate outside acceptable limits or if the resulting product is unacceptable, the process being applied or the materials being produced must be adjusted
options.C: The emergent process and work must be visible to those performing the work as well as those receiving the work
options.D: None of the answers apply

answers: The Scrum artifacts and the progress toward agreed goals must be inspected frequently and diligently to detect potentially undesirable variances or problems

Scrum events are designed to provoke change."

question: True or False. It's up to the self-managing team to decide which Scrum events are needed in the project.
answers: No
explanation: Self-management is not unlimited, they should follow the Scrum framework.

question: The performance of the Sprint should be measured at least _____________

options.C: Once a day
options.D: Once a Sprint
options.E: Before and after each release

answers: The performance of the Sprint should be measured at least Once a day
explanation: The performance of the project should be measured at least once per Sprint by the Product Owner, and the Sprint performance should be measured daily by the Developers.

question: Which of the following is not correct about the Developers?

options.A: Can make changes to the Sprint Backlog
options.C: Prioritizes tasks in the Sprint Backlog
options.D: Manage the Product Backlog

answers: Manage the Product Backlog
explanation: Both the Developers and the whole Scrum Team are cross-functional, but of course you can have Developers playing the Product Owner and Scrum Master accountability, so Developers can be cross-functional. The Product Backlog is owned and managed by the Product Owner. Developers own the Sprint Backlog, and are the only accountability that can make changes to it.

question: True or False. Since the Product Owner is accountable for the value of the product, they have the final say over the Definition of Done.
answers: No
explanation: The whole Scrum Team is responsible for the Definition of Done not the Product Owner.

question: A company that is mature in using Scrum and also has a PMO. What should be the accountability of the PMO?

options.A: Manages portfolios and programs and facilitates the application of techniques that complement Serum
options.B: There’s no place for a PMO in such an organization

question: True or False. Daily Scrums are held at the same time and same place every day.
answers: Yes
explanation: As stated in the Scrum Guide "To reduce complexity, it is held at the same time and place every working day of the Sprint."

question: Which of the following is a formal opportunity for inspecting and adapting?

options.D: Burn-down chart

answers: Sprint Review
explanation: Sprint Planning, Daily Scrum, Sprint Review, and Sprint Retrospective are formal opportunities for inspecting and adapting and they are considered feedback loops.

question: True or False. When multiple teams are working on one product, they should select work from the same Product Backlog.

question: True or False. The Scrum Master shouldn't allow the Developers to start working without having the tasks identified and assigned to themselves.

explanation:

Developers own the Sprint Backlog and they should do it by themselves.

explanation: Scrum can be applied to multiple teams, known as Scaled Scrum.

question: The CEO asks the Developers to add a "very important" item to a Sprint that is in progress. What should the Developers do?

options.A: Add the item to the current Sprint and drop an item of equal size
options.B: Add the item to the next Sprint
options.C: Add the item to the current Sprint without any adjustments
options.D: Inform the Product Owner so he/she can work with the CEO

answers: Inform the Product Owner so he/she can work with the CEO
explanation: The items selected for a Sprint have been selected as most valuable with the Product Owner. The items serve the Sprint's goal. No changes should be made that endanger the Sprint Goal. No one external to the Scrum Team can force changes on the Developers.

question: How much work must Developers do to a Product Backlog item they select for a Sprint?

options.A: As much as they have been told by the Product Owner will be done for every Product Backlog item they select in conformance with the Definition of Done
options.B: All development work and at least some testing
options.C: As much as they can fit into the Sprint
options.D: Analysis, design, programming, testing and documentation

answers: As much as they have been told by the Product Owner will be done for every Product Backlog item they select in conformance with the Definition of Done
explanation: The purpose of each Sprint is to deliver Increments of potentially releasable functionality that adhere to the Scrum Team's current definition of "Done".

question: True or False. The purpose of all Sprints is to create an Increment of work that meets the Definition of Done, a piece of working software usable and potentially releasable, however team doesn't need release every Sprint, but eventually, the team must release its work.
answers: Yes
explanation: The purpose of all Sprints is to create an Increment of Done work, a piece of working software usable and potentially releasable. However, the team doesn't need to release every Sprint, but eventually the team must release its work otherwise there is no point in doing the work for something that will never be released.

question: True or False. The Product Owner should determine how many items should be selected for the Sprint Backlog in the Sprint.
answers: No
explanation: It's only up to the self-managing Scrum Team to decide how many items they will select for the Sprint Backlog, not the Product Owner by himself/herself.

question: The Product Owner has some concerns about the Definition of Done. What should they do?

options.A: Adjust the Definition of Done immediately
options.B: Discuss it in the next Sprint Retrospective meeting
options.C: None of the answers apply
options.D: Have the team adjust it at the end of the Sprint
options.E: Adjust the Definition of Done at the end of the Sprint

answers: Discuss it in the next Sprint Retrospective meeting
