explanation: It's better to wait until the end of the Sprint before changing the Definition of Done. The Product Owner can present ideas, opinions, and arguments about the change, but the decision belongs to the whole Scrum Team.

question: Which statement best describes the Sprint Review?

options.A: It is when the Scrum Team and stakeholders inspect the outcome of a Sprint and figure out what to do next
options.B: It is a demo at the end of the Sprint for everyone in the organization to check on the work done
options.C: It is a mechanism to control the Developers’ activities during a Sprint

answers: It is when the Scrum Team and stakeholders inspect the outcome of a Sprint and figure out what to do next
explanation: Scrum Events in Scrum are opportunities to inspect and adapt.

question: Select the Scrum Values:

options.B: Individuals and Iteration, Working Software, Customer Collaboration, Responding to Change
options.C: Simplicity, Communication, Feedback, Respect, Courage
options.D: Transparency, Inspection, Adaptation

answers: Commitment, Courage, Focus, Openness, Respect
explanation: The Scrum values named in the Scrum guide are Commitment, Courage, Focus, Openness, Respect. The Scrum Theory Pillars are Transparency, Inspection, Adaptation.

question: When does Product Backlog refinement occur?

options.C: During the Sprint, in preparation for the next Sprint(s)
options.D: During Sprint 0

answers: During the Sprint, in preparation for the next Sprint(s)
explanation: Product Backlog refinement is the act of breaking down and further defining Product Backlog items into smaller more precise items. This is an ongoing activity to add details, such as a description, order, and size. Attributes often vary with the domain of work.

question: Which statement best describes Scrum?

options.A: A cookbook that defines best practices for software development
options.B: Scrum is a lightweight framework that helps people, teams and
options.C: organizations generate value through adaptive solutions for complex problems
options.D: A defined and predictive process that conforms to the principles of Scientific Management
options.E: A complete methodology that defines how to develop software

answers: Scrum is a lightweight framework that helps people, teams and
explanation: Scrum is not a process or a technique for building products, it is a framework within which you can employ various processes and techniques. As stated in the Scrum Guide "Scrum is a lightweight framework that helps people, teams and organizations generate value through adaptive solutions for complex problems."

question: If you are trying to find a "formal opportunity to inspect and adapt" in Scrum, which of the following would you consider? (Select the best three answers)

options.C: Product Backlog refinement
options.D: Sprint Review
options.E: Sprint Retrospective

answers: Sprint Planning and Sprint Review and Sprint Retrospective
explanation: Sprint Planning, Daily Scrum, Sprint Review, and Sprint Retrospective are "formal opportunities for inspecting and adapting", and are considered "feedback loops". Note that "formal opportunity" means "serious opportunity" or "important opportunity" here, and those are not "formal meetings", meaning that we don't exchange signatures and worry about contractual aspects during them.

question: True or False. The purpose of a Sprint is to produce an Increment of working software.
answers: Yes
explanation: The heart of Scrum is a Sprint, a timebox of one month or less during which a "Done", usable, and potentially releasable product Increment should be created.

question: Which of the following actions do not occur during the first Sprint? (Select the best two answers)

options.C: Develop something of value to the customer
options.D: Define the complete architecture

answers: Finalize the complete Product Backlog and Define the complete architecture
explanation: The Scrum Team should develop at least one Increment that could potentially be released. Make sure you have noticed the word "not" in the question.

question: The Developers should have all the skills needed to __________

options.A: Complete the project as estimated when the date and cost are committed to the Product Owner
options.B: Turn the Product Backlog items it selects into an Increment of potentially releasable product functionality
options.C: Do all of the development work, except for specialized testing that requires additional tools and environments

answers: The Developers should have all the skills needed to Turn the Product Backlog items it selects into an Increment of potentially releasable product functionality
explanation: The Developers consist of professionals who do the work of delivering a potentially releasable Increment that meet the Definition of Done. Scrum Teams are cross-functional, with all of the skills as a team necessary to create a product Increment.

question: True or False. The Sprint Review can impact the Sprint Planning meeting.
answers: Yes
explanation: It's true because in the Sprint Review the Scrum Team and stakeholders review what was accomplished in the Sprint and what has changed in their environment. Based on this information, attendees collaborate on what to do next, which is something that is planned during Sprint Planning.

question: True or False. The Scrum Team should choose at least one high priority process improvement, identified during the Sprint Retrospective, and place it in the Product Backlog.
answers: No
explanation: False, this used to be true with the previous version of the Scrum Guide. However we should underline that if the team finds it useful they can do it, it's not prohibited.

question: Which of the following statements are correct about the Definition of Done? (Select the best two answers)

options.A: It helps the Product Owner measure the progress of the Sprint work
options.B: Can be improved during the project
options.C: There should be one Definition of Done when multiple teams are working on the same project
options.D: Describes the purpose of each Sprint

answers: Can be improved during the project and There should be one Definition of Done when multiple teams are working on the same project
explanation: If there are multiple Scrum Teams working together on a product, they must mutually define and comply with the same Definition of Done and of course they can improve it as they learn more.

question: The Developers are ready to start the first Sprint, but the Product Backlog is not ready yet. What should the Product Owner do?

options.A: Ask the Developers to help refine the Product Backlog instead of starting the first Sprint
options.B: Let the Sprint begin, but only with the goal of completing the Product Backlog
options.C: Let the team start the first Sprint, and continue refining the Product Backlog

answers: Let the team start the first Sprint, and continue refining the Product Backlog
explanation: First, remember that the Product Backlog is never complete, and you don't have to wait until you have everything in the Product Backlog to start the first Sprint. However, this question says that the backlog is not ready, which probably means that the items at the top are too large and/or unclear. Again, having unready items is not a reason to wait, it's undesirable though, but you can refine them during the Sprint.

question: Developers should not be interrupted during the Sprint. The Sprint Goal should remain intact. These are conditions that foster creativity, quality and productivity. Based on this, which of the following is not right.

options.A: The Product Owner can help clarify or optimize the Sprint when asked by the Developers
options.B: The Developers may work with the Product Owner to remove or add work if it finds it has more or less capacity than it expected
options.C: The Sprint Backlog is fully formulated in the Sprint Planning meeting and does not change during the Sprint
options.D: As a decomposition of the selected Product Backlog Items, the Sprint Backlog changes and may grow as the work emerges

answers: The Sprint Backlog is fully formulated in the Sprint Planning meeting and does not change during the Sprint
explanation: Sprint Backlog can change only from the Developers as more is learnt during the Sprint. Only the Developers can change it, not someone externally. Make sure you have noticed the word "not" in the question.

question: Who is responsible for managing the progress of work during a Sprint?

options.A: The most junior member of the Team
options.C: The Developers
options.D: The Product Owner

answers: The Developers
explanation: The Developers use the Daily Scrum to inspect progress toward the Sprint Goal and to inspect how progress is trending toward completing the work in the Sprint Backlog and they are responsible for it.

question: Select the most appropriate ways that the Product Owner can use to inspect the Increment. (Select the best two answers)

options.A: By reviewing the Product Backlog during refinement
options.B: By inviting stakeholders to give feedback in the Sprint review
options.C: By presenting the status of the Product Backlog during the Sprint Review
options.D: By attending the Sprint Retrospective

answers: By inviting stakeholders to give feedback in the Sprint review and By presenting the status of the Product Backlog during the Sprint Review
explanation: At the Sprint Review the Product Owner shares the current state of Product Backlog, which, combined with the inspection of the Increment. This leads to an updated Product Backlog.

question: The timebox of this Scrum Event should be no more than three hours.

options.C: Sprint Retrospective
options.D: Release Planning
options.E: Release Sprint

answers: Sprint Retrospective
explanation: The Sprint Retrospective concludes the Sprint. It is timeboxed to a maximum of three hours for a one-month Sprint. For shorter Sprints, the event is usually shorter.

question: True or False. Only the Scrum Team is allowed to attend the Sprint Planning.
answers: No
explanation: Sprint Planning is attended by the entire Scrum Team. Stakeholders may attend by invitation of the team, it is not prohibited.

question: True or False. The Sprint Goal and the Sprint Backlog are the outputs of the Sprint Planning meeting.
answers: Yes
explanation: The whole Scrum Team then collaborates to define a Sprint Goal that communicates why the Sprint is valuable to stakeholders. The Sprint Goal must be finalized prior to the end of Sprint Planning. Sprint Backlog should be determined as well.

question: Who is responsible for maximizing the value of Product Backlog?

options.C: The Product Owner
options.D: The Scrum Team
options.E: The stakeholders

answers: The Product Owner
explanation: The Product Owner manages the Product Backlog, so it's up to her/him to decide the order. She/He should do it based on the value of the Items, remember the PO is also known as value maximizer.

question: In the middle of a Sprint, the customer asks for two important new features. Which of the following statements are inappropriate actions the Product Owner can take? (Select the best three answers)

options.A: Ask the Scrum Master to add the items to the Sprint Backlog
options.B: Add the items to the Product Backlog
options.C: Reject the request, because it’s in the middle of the Sprint
options.D: Ask the Developers if they can add them to the current Sprint Backlog
options.E: Assign those items to Developers in the next Daily Scrum

answers: Ask the Scrum Master to add the items to the Sprint Backlog and Reject the request, because it’s in the middle of the Sprint and Assign those items to Developers in the next Daily Scrum
explanation: Only the Developers assign work to themselves, and their work items come from the Sprint Backlog. Only the Developers make changes to the Sprint Backlog.

question: What are the classic questions of Daily Scrums, if you decide to go through them? (Select the best three answers)

options.A: What work am I going to do today to help the team achieve its goal?
options.B: What problems did I have yesterday?
options.C: What impediments are in my way or in the way of the team?
options.D: How many hours did I spend on the project yesterday?
options.E: What work did I do yesterday to help the team achieve its goal?
options.F: Are we able to deliver all Sprint Backlog items by the end of the Sprint?

answers: What work am I going to do today to help the team achieve its goal? and What impediments are in my way or in the way of the team? and What work did I do yesterday to help the team achieve its goal?
explanation: It's not mandatory to use these questions, but very common and recommended.

question: Raffaele is a Scrum Master helping an organization to establish five Scrum Teams that will be developing a product. Raffaele discusses with the teams the high level of integration that the product Increment will require by the end of their first Sprint. It is a highly anticipated product, both by consumers and by the organization. Of the options raised by the future team members, which option should Raffaele encourage?

options.A: Each Scrum Team delivers done Increments in its own area of responsibility. Upon functional acceptance at the Sprint Review, the code is isolated for future stabilization. The release date is adjusted according to the expected work and time of such integration phase
options.B: Each team provides a separate Increment with the functionality added by the individual team. The Sprint Review is used to identify the work needed to integrate with the other teams. This work is then added to the Product Backlog
options.C: In the first Sprint, integration ¡s less important. The goal is to deliver business value. Functionality that is not integrated with the work of other Scrum Teams by the end of a Sprint is still reviewed to assess its potential business value. It can still be released at the Product Owner’s discretion, and silent consent of the stakeholders
options.D: All Scrum Teams agree on a shared Definition of Done describing all work needed to deliver an Increment for review that is the integrated sum of the work of all Scrum Teams on the initiative

answers: All Scrum Teams agree on a shared Definition of Done describing all work needed to deliver an Increment for review that is the integrated sum of the work of all Scrum Teams on the initiative
explanation: As stated in the Scrum Guide "If there are multiple Scrum Teams working together on a product, they must mutually define and comply with the same Definition of Done."

question: Which of the following statements are correct about the number of Product Owners when there are three products being developed using Scrum? (Select the best two answers)

options.A: There can be a different Product Owner for each product
options.B: Each product should have a separate Product Owner
options.C: There can be a single Product Owner for all products
options.D: There should be only one Product Owner working with a Development manager for both products

answers: There can be a different Product Owner for each product and There can be a single Product Owner for all products
explanation: It is not mandatory to have exactly 3 people as Product Owners. Each Product should have a single Product Owner. You can also have two Product Owners for three products and one of them has to manage two products, that's why we have to be careful in the wording of the options.

question: Who is accountable to know the most about the progress toward a business objective or a release, and be able to explain clearly the alternatives?

options.C: The Delivery Manager
options.D: The Development Manager
options.E: The Developers

answers: The Product Owner
explanation: The Product Owner needs to make sure that he keeps the Developers updated with what the clients & stakeholders need. The Scrum Master is there to coach him/her on how to do it.

question: Which of the following should not change during the Sprint?

options.C: Sprint Backlog
options.D: Minimum level of quality

answers: Minimum level of quality
explanation: Product Backlog may change at any time. The level of expected quality shouldn't decrease during the Sprint. The tasks in the Sprint Backlog are always changing as more is learnt. Also, The Scrum Guide is not against changing the "items" in the Sprint Backlog either. Those that stay fixed during the Sprint are needed to avoid distractions, and create a more productive environment. After all, Sprints are not so long that they create problems.

question: Who has the final say on the order of the Product Backlog?

options.C: All answers apply
options.D: The Stakeholders
options.E: The Product Owner

answers: The Product Owner
explanation: The Product Owner is the sole person responsible for managing the Product Backlog.

question: Who must do the work required for Product Backlog items, in order to create a potentially releasable Increment?

options.C: The Scrum Master
options.D: The Product Owner

answers: The Developers
explanation: Developers are the people in the Scrum Team that are committed to creating any aspect of a usable Increment each Sprint, as stated in the Scrum Guide.

question: Upon what type of process control is Scrum based?

options.C: Empirical
options.D: Defined

answers: Empirical
explanation: Scrum is founded on empirical process control theory, or empiricism. Empiricism asserts that knowledge comes from experience and making decisions based on what is known.

question: True or False. It is mandatory that the product Increment be released to production at the end of each Sprint.
answers: No
explanation: The product Increment should be usable and releasable at the end of every Sprint, but it does not have to be released. It's the Product Owner's decision to release it.

question: The Scrum Values promote Scrum Teams to be cross-functional and have all the skills needed to build a product within the team. While starting Scrum, what would be the advantages of keeping the existing component teams (e.g. design, database, back-end, front-end)?

options.A: Component teams generally have all the skills needed to deliver shippable Increments that add business value
options.B: There is less communication overhead than working in feature teams
options.C: Component teams would have all the skills needed to focus on their specific technical layer
options.D: Because their productivity is already predictable, they can deliver shippable Increments more quickly than a newly formed team
options.E: Because they have been working together for some time, there will be less initial disruption than a newly formed team. As they begin working, they will discover what works best and how to move towards cross-functional teams

answers: Because they have been working together for some time, there will be less initial disruption than a newly formed team. As they begin working, they will discover what works best and how to move towards cross-functional teams
explanation: The ones that will be doing the work are the best ones to decide on what Scrum Team structures work best.

question: When does the next Sprint begin?

options.A: When the Product Owner is ready
options.C: Immediately following the next Sprint Planning
options.D: Immediately after the conclusion of the previous Sprint

answers: Immediately after the conclusion of the previous Sprint
explanation: A new Sprint starts immediately after the conclusion of the previous Sprint. There is no gap between them.

question: True or False. Each increment is independent from the previous one
answers: No
explanation: Each Increment is additive to all prior Increments and thoroughly verified, ensuring that all Increments work together. In order to provide value, the Increment must be usable.

question: What's the commitment of the Increment?

options.C: Definition of Ready
options.D: Product Goal

answers: Definition of Done
explanation: An Increment is a concrete stepping stone toward the Product Goal. Work cannot be considered part of an Increment unless it meets the Definition of Done.

question: How does the Product Owner manage the value of the product?

options.C: MoSCow Analysis
options.D: Customer feedback via frequent releases

answers: Product Backlog Order and Customer feedback via frequent releases
explanation: Product Owner's responsibility is to manage the Product Backlog, so that maximum value can be delivered. He/She can achieve this via frequent releases so that the feedback loop is as short as possible.

question: How should a Scrum Master respond if the Product Owner plans the first Sprint to only focus on setting up the infrastructure and architecture in order to work on functionality in a subsequent Sprint?

options.A: Support the Product Owner’s decision as he/she is accountable for maximizing the value of the work that the Developers do
options.B: Help the Product Owner understand the value of including business functionality into every Sprint and explain to him/her that the best architecture and infrastructure emerge alongside the development of the functionality
options.C: Explain that one Sprint may be too short to finish the architecture and he should pre-allocate subsequent Sprints just in case
options.D: Add at least one technical architect to the Scrum Team to ensure the architecture can be completed in the first Sprint

answers: Help the Product Owner understand the value of including business functionality into every Sprint and explain to him/her that the best architecture and infrastructure emerge alongside the development of the functionality
explanation: Improving communications with the customers and stakeholders is a crucial activity in Scrum. It reduces waste from building items that add no value. Saying that, the best architectures, requirements, and designs emerge from self-managing teams.

question: You are the Scrum Master for four Scrum Teams working on one product. Several of the Developers notify you that their teams will need full-time help from an external technical specialist Helen in the upcoming two Sprints. What key concerns should the Scrum Master take into account?

options.B: The benefit of teams solving the problem themselves and the
options.C: ability to produce integrated Increments
options.D: Hiring additional resources to fill the void in the skill set
options.E: Having enough work for all team members

answers: The benefit of teams solving the problem themselves and the
explanation: The Scrum Master needs to coach the Developers to work in a way that they don't depend on Helen and they can take ownership of this issue by themselves.

question: Veronica is a Scrum Master of a new team that is going to start a new Project. Which of the following actions may Veronica take in starting up the Project? (Select the best three answers)

options.A: Ask the Developers to discuss and identify the way they are going to develop the product
options.B: Ensure that a bonus system is in place for the top performance of individuals
options.C: Ask the Developers to introduce themselves to each other and describe their skills and background
options.D: Ask the Product Owner to explain the project, its business needs, history, goals, and context
options.E: Ask the development managers to introduce their departments and capabilities
options.F: Ensure that team members have clear roles and responsibilities

answers: Ask the Developers to discuss and identify the way they are going to develop the product and Ask the Developers to introduce themselves to each other and describe their skills and background and Ask the Product Owner to explain the project, its business needs, history, goals, and context
explanation: The rest are wrong because: Having a reward system is harmful to the unity of the team. Members share accountability, and they do not have different roles and responsibilities. It has to be about the project and the people internal to it, not the external departments. Remember that the team is cross-functional and does everything needed for the project, without outside help.

question: John is the Product Owner of two Scrum Teams. Which of the following statements are true? (Select the best two answers)

options.A: Optimizing the value of the work the Developers perform
options.B: Is another name for the Project Manager
options.C: All his time must be dedicated to a single project
options.D: Ordering the items in the Product Backlog to best achieve goals and missions

answers: Optimizing the value of the work the Developers perform and Ordering the items in the Product Backlog to best achieve goals and missions
explanation: The Product Owner is responsible for maximizing the value of the product resulting from work of the Developers and prioritize the Product Backlog items accordingly. There is no accountability of Project Manager or equivalent in the Scrum framework.

question: The Developers are trying to convince Alexander the Product Owner that the Sprint should be cancelled with no obvious reason. What's the right response from Nina the Scrum Master to do?

options.A: Nina should tell the Developers that it is okay. The Product Owner knows more about it
options.B: Nina should encourage Alexander to discuss it with the customer first
options.C: Nina should be involved in making this decision
options.D: Nina should stop this, because the Developers do not have the authority to influence Sprint cancellation

answers: Nina should tell the Developers that it is okay. The Product Owner knows more about it
explanation: The Product Owner is the only person who can cancel the Sprint. Developers can raise concerns but not without any specific reason. Product Owners receive input from everyone who's involved in the project when they are making their decisions and they know more about it.

question: During a Sprint, a Scrum Team determines that it will not be able to finish the complete forecast. Who should be present to review and adjust the Sprint work selected?

options.C: The Product Owner and the Developers
options.D: The Developers
options.E: The Scrum Master, the project manager and the Developers
options.F: The Product Owner and all stakeholders

answers: The Product Owner and the Developers
explanation: During the Sprint, scope may be clarified and re-negotiated between the Product Owner and Developers as more is learned.

question: Which of the following do the Developers do during the first Sprint? (Select the best two answers)

options.A: Develop a plan for the rest of the release
options.B: Determine the complete architecture and infrastructure for the product
options.C: Deliver an Increment of potentially releasable software
options.D: Create the complete Product Backlog to be developed in subsequent Sprints
options.E: Develop and deliver at least one piece of functionality

answers: Deliver an Increment of potentially releasable software and Develop and deliver at least one piece of functionality
explanation: The core of Scrum is a Sprint, a timebox of one month or less during which a "Done", usable, and potentially releasable product Increment is created. This applies to every Sprint.

question: At the beginning of the Sprint, the Developers don't have the tools and infrastructure needed to complete the current Sprint Backlog Items. What of the following statements are least appropriate for the Scrum Master to do? (Select the best two answers)

options.A: The Increment for current Sprint will focus on delivering infrastructure and tool acquisition
options.B: Improve communication between the Product Owner and Developers in order to establish a plausible Sprint Goal and a proper Definition of Done
options.C: Talk with the Product Owner in order to accept partially done Increments
options.D: Help the Developers to get tools and improve infrastructure while Definition of Done is adapted accordingly

answers: The Increment for current Sprint will focus on delivering infrastructure and tool acquisition and Talk with the Product Owner in order to accept partially done Increments
explanation: Infrastructure and tools are not prepared upfront, because it requires a complete understanding of the whole project and product, which is usually not the case, so we need to hold on to the adaptation pillar. The required infrastructure and tools will be prepared gradually through the project because they depend on the product we’re going to create, which in turn is defined through the project. Make sure you have noticed the "least appropriate" in the question.

question: Who keeps track of the remaining work in the Product Backlog?

options.C: Senior Executives
options.D: The Scrum Team
options.E: The Scrum Master

answers: The Product Owner
explanation: Product Owner's responsibility is to manage the Product Backlog, so that maximum value can be delivered. He/She is the one who knows more about it.

question: You are a Scrum Master and were asked to conduct an interview by management for a new team member. Which characteristics would you look for in the candidate?

options.C: Team Player
options.D: Generalizing Specialist

answers: Generalizing Specialist
explanation: Generalizing Specialists are most preferred in a Scrum Team. They can perform more than one role/accountability.

question: Which of the below are accountabilities on a Scrum Team?

options.C: Scrum Master
options.D: Product Owner
options.E: Customers

answers: Developers and Scrum Master and Product Owner
explanation: The Scrum Team consists of a Product Owner, the Developers, and a Scrum Master.

question: What is the main reason for the Scrum Master to be at the Daily Scrum?

options.A: He or she does not have to be there; he or she only has to ensure the Developers have a Daily Scrum
options.B: To gather status and progress information to report to management
options.C: To make sure every team member answers the three questions
options.D: To write down any changes to the Sprint Backlog, including adding new items, and tracking progress on the burn-down

answers: He or she does not have to be there; he or she only has to ensure the Developers have a Daily Scrum
explanation: The Scrum Master enforces the rule that only Developers participate in the Daily Scrum. Others can join as listeners though.

question: What represents the trend line in a burndown chart, through a Sprint?

options.A: The changes of the cost through the current Sprint
options.B: The amount of remaining technical debt
options.C: The remaining work to be completed if nothing changes on the
options.D: Sprint Backlog or the Scrum Team
options.E: The date when the Scrum Team can be released for other work

answers: The remaining work to be completed if nothing changes on the
explanation: The trend line gives us visibility about the forecast for the finishing date, considering a constant Scrum Team capacity for the Sprint Backlog.

question: The Product Backlog is ordered by _________

options.A: Whatever is deemed most appropriate by the Product Owner
options.C: Risk, where safer items are at the top, and riskier items are at the bottom
options.D: Size, where small items are at the top and large items are at the bottom
options.E: Least valuable items at the top to most valuable at the bottom

answers: The Product Backlog is ordered by Whatever is deemed most appropriate by the Product Owner
explanation: The Product Owner decides what makes the most sense to optimize the value of the work being done by the Developers.

question: The Product Owner is not working with the Developers during the Sprint. What would you do as a Scrum Master?

options.A: Talk to the functional manager of the Product Owner
options.B: Cancel the Sprint and start training the Product Owner
options.C: Nominate someone else as the proxy Product Owner
options.D: Bring up the issue in the next Sprint Retrospective

answers: Bring up the issue in the next Sprint Retrospective
explanation: There's no proxy Product Owner in Scrum. It's best to resolve issues internally, without managers. This is not a valid reason for canceling a Sprint, and if it was only the Product Owner can cancel the Sprint.

question: Which of the following are optional in Scrum? (Select the best two answers)

options.C: Burndown
options.D: Increment
options.E: Definition of Done

answers: Velocity and Burndown
explanation: Burndown and Velocity are not mentioned in the Scrum Guide, however they are useful and they are mostly used by the Scrum Teams.

question: From the following options, what is the best way a Scrum Master can increase the team productivity?

options.A: Breaking down the most valued Product Backlog items
options.B: Causing the removal of impediments and facilitating Scrum events if requested
options.C: Implementing a control change board
options.D: Assigning tasks to Developers

answers: Causing the removal of impediments and facilitating Scrum events if requested
explanation: Causing the removal of impediments and facilitating the Scrum events as requested or needed are the kind of things expected from the Scrum Master. The Scrum Team is self-managed, the Scrum Master must ensure the Product Owner knows how to prioritize the Product Backlog to maximize its value, but the Scrum Master is not responsible for doing so.

question: Which of the following statements do not explain when a Product Backlog item is considered complete? (Select the best two answers)

options.A: The item is ready for user acceptance testing
options.B: When the customer approves its completeness
options.C: When everything is done based on the Definition of Done
options.D: When there’s nothing more we need to do before it can be used by end users

answers: The item is ready for user acceptance testing and When the customer approves its completeness
explanation: We can't consider it Done when user acceptance testing is not done. If we are aware of something that it's missing we should implement it, before considering it Done. A Product Backlog item that you have in the Sprint Backlog is Done, when it can be part of a Done Increment. Increments have to be Done based on the Definition of Done.

question: A baselined Product Backlog is called __________

options.C: Sprint Backlog
options.D: Product Road map
options.E: It is never baselined, ¡t is a living artifact

answers: A baselined Product Backlog is called It is never baselined, ¡t is a living artifact
explanation: The product backlog is often called a living artifact, since it is continuously updated to reflect changes in the project and customer feedback.

question: The timebox for a Daily Scrum is ________

options.A: 15 minutes for a 4 week Sprint. For shorter Sprints it is usually shorter
options.C: Two minutes per person
options.D: The same time of day every day
options.E: 4 hours

answers: The timebox for a Daily Scrum is 15 minutes
explanation: The Daily Scrum is timeboxed at 15 minutes, it does not change depending on the length of a Sprint.

question: Which statement best describes a Product Owner's responsibility?

options.A: Optimizing the value of the work the Developers do
options.C: Keep stakeholders from distracting the Developers
options.D: Managing the project and ensuring that the work meets the commitments to the stakeholders

answers: Optimizing the value of the work the Developers do
explanation: The Product Owner is responsible for maximizing the value of the product and the work of the Developers and making sure that the Product Backlog reflects maximum value towards the Product Goal.

question: True or False. Work that does not meet the Definition of Done should be completed in the next Sprint.
answers: No
explanation: It should be moved in the Product Backlog and let the Product Owner decide what to do with it.

question: True or False. Multiple Scrum Teams should use the Definition of Ready to normalize estimations. This way it will be easier to measure and compare their performance
answers: No
explanation: There are no comparable estimation units between the Scrum Teams, each team is different. Definition of Ready is a common practice, but is not mandatory in Scrum. The purpose of DoR is not normalizing estimations or performance measuring anyway.

question: True or False. Scrum does not have an accountability called Project Manager.
answers: Yes
explanation: A Scrum Team has a Scrum Master, a Product Owner and Developers. As a whole they have all controls needed and Project Manager is not an accountability in Scrum.

question: A new Developer has just joined an existing team that has been together for several Sprints. During the Sprint, the individual has been trying to share his ideas and viewpoints but is continuously ignored by the rest of the Developers. Which Scrum Values has the Scrum Team been neglecting? (Select the best three answers)

options.C: Courage
options.D: Respect
options.E: Focus

answers: Openness and Courage and Respect
explanation: The Scrum Team members have courage to do the right thing and work on challenging problems. The Scrum Team agrees to be open to discuss all the work and the challenges with performing the work. Scrum Team members respect each other’s skills, experience and opinions.

question: When does a Developer become the sole owner of a Sprint Backlog item?

options.A: Never. All Sprint Backlog Items are “owned” by all Developers, even though each one may be implemented by an individual member
options.B: Whenever a team member can accommodate more work
options.C: During the Daily Scrum
options.D: At the Sprint planning meeting

answers: Never. All Sprint Backlog Items are “owned” by all Developers, even though each one may be implemented by an individual member
explanation: Sprint Backlog and all of its items are collectively owned by the Developers. No individual Developer can claim ownership over an item as this would block communication and collaboration.

question: True or False. Stakeholders are prohibited to be present in the Daily Scrum
answers: No
explanation: Stakeholders can be in Daily Scrum as listeners, however only the Developers must participate and talk.

question: An organization has decided to adopt Scrum, but management wants to change the terminology to fit with terminology already used. What will likely happen if this is done?

options.B: The organization may not understand what has changed with Scrum and the benefits of Scrum may be lost
options.C: All answers apply
options.D: Without a new vocabulary as a reminder of the change, very little change may actually happen
options.E: None of the answers apply

answers: All answers apply
explanation: It's not easy to transform an organization that is new to Scrum, it will take time to see the benefit of it. Forming the organization takes time, and members often go through recognizable stages as they change from being a group of individuals to a team with common goals. Forming, Storming, Norming, and Performing model describes these stages by Bruce Tuckman. When you understand it, you can help your new team become effective more quickly.

question: What is the timebox for a Sprint Planning meeting?

options.A: 8 hours for a monthly Sprint. For shorter Sprints it is usually shorter
options.C: Monthly
options.D: Whenever it is done

answers: 8 hours for a monthly Sprint. For shorter Sprints it is usually shorter
explanation: Sprint Planning is timeboxed to a maximum of eight hours for a one-month Sprint. For shorter Sprints, the event is usually shorter.

question: What should be the duration of a Sprint?

options.A: Short enough to be able to synchronize the development work with other business processes
options.B: Sufficiently short to maintain acceptable business risks for the product owner
options.C: None of the answers apply
options.D: No more than one month
options.E: All of the answers apply

answers: All of the answers apply
explanation: All these choices are correct criteria in deciding the duration of a Sprint. When a Sprint’s horizon is too long the Sprint Goal may become invalid, complexity may rise, and risk may increase. Shorter Sprints can be employed to generate more learning cycles and limit risk of cost and effort to a smaller time frame.

question: Stakeholders joined the Daily Scrum of a Scrum Team to add a really urgent Bug in the Sprint Backlog. Developers immediately understood that they have to fix it as soon as possible, so they added it into the Sprint Backlog. Which of the following statements is wrong?

options.A: The fact that stakeholders joined the Daily Scrum
options.B: The fact that the Developers accepted work from stakeholders
options.C: The fact that the Developers didn’t redirect the stakeholders to the Product Owner
options.D: The fact that stakeholders spoke in the Daily Scrum

answers: The fact that the Developers accepted work from stakeholders and The fact that the Developers didn’t redirect the stakeholders to the Product Owner and The fact that stakeholders spoke in the Daily Scrum
explanation: It is acceptable for the stakeholders to join the Daily Scrum, but they can only be there as listeners, they shouldn't interrupt the Developers. Even if stakeholders approach the Developers directly, they should be redirected to the Product Owner and if it is really urgent, PO could even cancel the Sprint, depending on what is going on with the Bug.

question: Who creates the Definition of Done?

options.A: The organization (or the Scrum Team if none is available from the organization)
options.B: The Scrum Master as he/she is responsible for the Developers’ productivity
options.C: The Product Owner as he/she is responsible for the product’s success
options.D: The Developers

answers: The organization (or the Scrum Team if none is available from the organization)
explanation: Note that it was the responsibility of the Developer to create the Definition of Done in the previous versions of the Scrum Guide, but it's the whole Scrum Team now. As stated in the Scrum Guide "The Scrum Team must create a Definition of Done appropriate for the product."

question: True or False. A 2x increase in the number of Developers will double productivity.
answers: No
explanation: When more Developers are added to the team, there's usually a short-term decrease in productivity because other members have to spend time and effort familiarizing the new members with the solution and the environment of the project. After a while, the existence of new members may increase productivity, but even if it does, it's usually not a linear increase because, for example, having more people increases communication channels, which consumes some of the capacity.

question: At the end of the Sprint the Developers have agreed to release the increment even if there is a part of it that doesn't meet the Definition of Done. The Product Owner said that it is alright, because they did Manual Testing instead of Test Automation. What shouldn't happen in this case?

options.A: The Developers shouldn’t tell the Product Owner that they should do Test Automation
options.B: They should discuss this in the Sprint Retrospective
options.C: The Serum Master shouldn’t be involved. Quality is not her/his responsibility
options.D: The Serum Master should ask coaching questions like “Do you think that the increment will give the same value with the missing testing?”
options.E: They should extend the Sprint until they finish Test Automation
options.F: They should add the Test Automation in the Product Backlog to avoid Technical Debt

answers: The Developers shouldn’t tell the Product Owner that they should do Test Automation and The Serum Master shouldn’t be involved. Quality is not her/his responsibility and They should extend the Sprint until they finish Test Automation
explanation: The Scrum Master should ask coaching questions when something is not properly followed (DoD). They shouldn't extend the Sprint, they should either exclude it from the increment or add it in the Product Backlog to avoid Technical Debt.

question: When is a Sprint over?

options.A: When the Product Owner says it is done
options.B: When all Product Backlog items meet their Definition of Done
options.C: When the timebox expires
options.D: When all the tasks are completed

answers: When the timebox expires
explanation: The duration of a Sprint is fixed and cannot be shortened or lengthened. A Sprint starts immediately after the end of the previous one.

question: During a Sprint, the customer complains that a critical functionality is missing. Which Scrum Events they might have to attend to provide feedback about the expected features?

options.C: Sprint Planning
options.D: Sprint Retrospective
options.E: Product Backlog refinement

answers: Sprint Review
explanation: During Sprint Review, the Scrum Team and stakeholders review what was accomplished in the Sprint and what has changed in their environment. Based on this information, attendees collaborate on what to do next, so the customers could be there to provide feedback. The Product Backlog may also be adjusted to meet new opportunities.

question: Which artifact contains a plan for making visible the Sprint Goal?

options.C: Sprint Backlog

answers: Sprint Backlog
explanation: The Sprint Backlog is composed of the Sprint Goal. Sprint Goal is the commitment. The Sprint Goal is the single objective for the Sprint.

question: What is the accountability of Management in Scrum?

options.A: Support the Product Owner with insights and information into high value product and system capabilities. Support the Scrum Master to cause organizational change that fosters empiricism, self-management, bottom-up intelligence, and intelligent release of software
options.C: Identity and remove people that aren’t working hard enough
options.D: Continually monitor staffing levels of the Developers

answers: Support the Product Owner with insights and information into high value product and system capabilities. Support the Scrum Master to cause organizational change that fosters empiricism, self-management, bottom-up intelligence, and intelligent release of software
explanation: Management has no active accountability in the actual product development through Scrum. However, management external to the Scrum Team is incredibly important in setting the vision and strategy to guide the overall direction of the organization.

question: True or False. The Product Owner can allow the Developers to create and add items to the Product Backlog.
answers: Yes
explanation: Product Owners are allowed to delegate some of their responsibilities to other team members. The Product Owner is still staying accountable for it.

question: True or False. If stakeholders want to add a new item in the Product Backlog, they have to convince the Product Owner.
answers: Yes
explanation: For Product Owners to succeed, the entire organization must respect their decisions. Those wanting to change the Product Backlog can do so by trying to convince the Product Owner.

question: A key stakeholder tells the Developers to cancel the current Sprint as the customer that requested this work has left the company, so the Sprint Goal is obsolete now. What should happen in this case?

options.A: Cancel the Sprint, as it is really obvious the Sprint Goal is obsolete
options.B: The Scrum Master should coach the stakeholders for ways to raise their concerns
options.C: Developers should refer the key stakeholder to the Product Owner and let him decide if the Sprint Goal is obsolete
options.D: The Scrum Master should coach the stakeholders that they should never speak to the Developers directly, they should go through the Product Owner
options.E: This is the only case that stakeholders could cancel a Sprint

answers: The Scrum Master should coach the stakeholders for ways to raise their concerns and Developers should refer the key stakeholder to the Product Owner and let him decide if the Sprint Goal is obsolete
explanation: Only the Product Owner has the right to cancel a Sprint, no matter what's the reason behind it. Stakeholders can talk directly to the Developers, they should collaborate if needed. The Scrum Master should always be there to coach when needed.

question: Which of the following statements best describe Lean thinking in Scrum?

options.C: Reduces waste
options.D: Limits the work in progress

answers: Focuses on the essentials and Reduces waste
explanation: As stated in the Scrum Guide "Scrum is founded on empiricism and lean thinking. Empiricism asserts that knowledge comes from experience and making decisions based on what is observed. Lean thinking reduces waste and focuses on the essentials."

question: True or False. Always must be a Release after each Sprint.
answers: No
explanation: The main purpose of the Sprint is to create an Increment of usable, and potentially releasable “Done” product. It's up to the Product Owner if it will be released.

question: What is the level of definition needed for the Sprint Backlog through the Sprint Planning?

options.B: The entire Sprint Backlog work must be identified and estimated by the end of the Sprint Planning
options.C: Enough to disaggregate tasks for the Scrum Team to establish the whole Sprint effort
options.D: Enough to allow the Developers to create their best forecast about what they can do as a result of the incoming Sprint, and to start the first several days of the Sprint
options.E: All answers apply

answers: Enough to allow the Developers to create their best forecast about what they can do as a result of the incoming Sprint, and to start the first several days of the Sprint
explanation: The Sprint Planning priority is covering three topics: Why is this Sprint valuable? What can be Done this Sprint? & How will the chosen work get done? The team doesn’t need to get all the details about every task as long as these questions are answered and the pending definition can be completed as soon as possible in refinement activities.

question: The Product Owner says that the customer has security concerns. Where can these concerns be addressed in Scrum? (Select the best two answers)

options.A: Can be added to the Product Backlog
options.B: Can be handled in a special dedicated Sprint
options.C: Can be handled by security experts contractors in some moment
options.D: Can be handled in the Definition of Done

answers: Can be added to the Product Backlog and Can be handled in the Definition of Done
explanation: Many non-functional features, like security, can be added as acceptance criteria and tests in the Definition of Done to be applied to all or some Product Backlog items. We can have some specific security concerns that can be items in the Product Backlog. The Developers are cross-functional and self-sufficient, and should be capable of taking care of every aspect of the product, including security.

question: Which of the following is a requirement before starting a Sprint Planning event?

options.A: Having the requirements specified and completely reflected in the Product Backlog
options.B: Having the Product Backlog items clearly described and assigned to developers
options.C: None of the answers apply
options.D: Having the items at the top of the Product Backlog small enough to fit into one Sprint
options.E: All answers apply

answers: None of the answers apply
explanation: Each Sprint Planning starts immediately after the Sprint Retrospective of the previous Sprint, which means there's nothing happening before the Sprint Planning. There is nothing that could stop the Developers from starting the Sprint. Even if they haven't done refinement they should start the Sprint and they will split the items as more is learnt.

question: True or False. The Product Owner can delegate some of their responsibilities to the Developers.
answers: Yes
explanation: Product Owners are allowed to delegate some of their responsibilities to other team members. If they do, the Product Owner stays accountable. Note: "responsible" is the person who's doing the task and "accountable" is the person who supervises it and is ultimately answerable for the task. The Product Owner is always accountable for the Product Backlog; they are also responsible unless they delegate this responsibility. These two words are often mixed though, so don't be shocked if you see that "responsible" is used to mean "accountable" sometimes.

question: Which of the following is misleading about the Increment?

options.A: Multiple Increments may be created within a Sprint
options.B: Each Increment is not additive to all prior Increments
options.C: It may be delivered to stakeholders prior to the end of the Sprint
options.D: It is a concrete stepping stone toward the Sprint Goal

answers: Each Increment is not additive to all prior Increments and It is a concrete stepping stone toward the Sprint Goal
explanation: An Increment is a concrete stepping stone toward the Product Goal. Each Increment is additive to all prior Increments and thoroughly verified, ensuring that all Increments work together. Multiple Increments may be created within a Sprint and may be delivered to stakeholders prior to the end of the Sprint.

question: What does a trend line through a release burndown chart indicate?

options.A: The budgeted cost of the project
options.B: When the remaining work ¡s supposed to be finished
options.C: When the remaining work will likely be completed if nothing changes in the Product Backlog or the Scrum Team
options.D: When the project will likely finish, if the team develops with a speed equal to the last Sprint

answers: When the remaining work will likely be completed if nothing changes in the Product Backlog or the Scrum Team
explanation: During a release, a product is transferred from the development team to the customer. The release burndown chart shows the team progress towards the release date by plotting the remaining effort against the ideal effort. If the remaining effort line or bar is above the ideal effort, the team is behind the schedule.

question: True or False. The Definition of Done can change during the project.
answers: Yes
explanation: Yes, it can be improved during the project. However, it doesn't change in the middle of a Sprint. During each Retrospective the Scrum Team could improve it if necessary.

question: True or False. Sprint Review is a meeting for receiving a customer's formal confirmation.
answers: No
explanation: Sprint Review is a Scrum Event not a meeting. It happens internally in the organization. All Scrum events are designed to be transparent, and to be used for inspection, and ultimately, adaptation.

question: Which of the following statements is a valid service from a Scrum Master to a Product Owner?

options.A: Help the Product Owner order the Product Backlog items in order to maximize value
options.B: Act as the middleman between the Product Owner and the Developers, as requested or required
options.C: Act as a proxy when the Product Owner is not available to the team
options.D: Help the Product Owner find techniques for managing the Product Backlog

answers: Help the Product Owner find techniques for managing the Product Backlog
explanation: It has to be coaching/training rather than doing the actual work. For example, helping the Product Owner order the backlog is not a good idea, but helping them understand how to order the backlog is a good one.

question: True or False. Stakeholders are only allowed to meet with the Scrum Team at Sprint Review.
answers: No
explanation: Improving communications with the stakeholders is a crucial activity in Scrum, as working with them frequently ensures the team can focus on the right things to build. Although it is useful to have stakeholders not only at Sprint Review, but also maybe during Product Backlog refinement. There should be collaboration between the Developers and the stakeholder to make sure that Developers are aligned with the value needed by the customers.

question: In this event, the Scrum Team and stakeholders talk and collaborate about what was done in the Sprint, in order to share the Sprint progress.

options.C: All answers apply
options.D: Daily Scrum

answers: Sprint Review
explanation: The Sprint Review event is held at the end of the Sprint to inspect the Increment and adapt the Product Backlog if needed. Attendees also collaborate on the next things that could be done to optimize value.

question: True or False. Only the Developers are required to attend the Daily Scrum meeting.
answers: Yes
explanation: It is mandatory for the Developers to be there and participate. However, others could join as listeners.

question: What topics does the Sprint Planning address?

options.A: How will the chosen work get done?
options.B: Who is going to work with who?
options.C: What can be Done this Sprint?
options.D: Why is this Sprint valuable?
options.E: Is there enough work to keep everyone busy full-time?

answers: How will the chosen work get done? and What can be Done this Sprint? and Why is this Sprint valuable?
explanation: Sprint Planning has nothing to do with who is doing what. It has to do with the work for the next Sprint and has to cover these three topics. Why is this Sprint valuable? What can be Done this Sprint? and How will the chosen work get done?

question: The timebox of this Scrum Event should be one month or less.

options.C: Sprint
options.D: None of the answers apply
options.E: Hardening Sprint

answers: Sprint
explanation: Sprints are fixed length events of one month or less to create consistency. A new Sprint starts immediately after the conclusion of the previous Sprint.

question: True or False. The Sprint Backlog contains only pulled items from Product Backlog.
answers: No
explanation: Of course, the Sprint Backlog contains the selected Product Backlog items but not just that. It also contains the tasks for the current Sprint which have agreed in the Sprint Planning for the delivery plan. (non-functional items, like testing etc.)

question: Which of the following is not a Developer responsibility?

options.A: Estimate the work needed for Sprint Backlog items
options.C: Measuring the performance of the Sprint
options.D: Ordering the Product Backlog items
options.E: Deal with internal team conflicts

answers: Ordering the Product Backlog items
explanation: Remember that Developers are self-managed. Therefore, It is team’ responsibility to measure its own productivity and performance throughout the Sprint, figure out its own process, plan, estimate and optimize the work required for items and the Sprint Goal, and to resolve their own conflicts.

question: Peter is a new Product Owner on a newly formed Scrum Team. Peter has projected a product completion date based on an estimated velocity of 21 completed points per Sprint. After the first 3 Sprints, the Developers have determined that their maximum velocity is 15 points and they are unable to create shippable Increments at the end of each Sprint. What is the best way to proceed?

options.A: Inform Peter that the projected completion date is not correct. The Developers would estimate the remaining work to produce a shippable Increment and suggest completing it (make it meet the Definition of Done). Based on empirical data, Peter can adjust the completion date and decide how to continue
options.B: Extend the Sprint in order to complete the Sprint Backlog items
options.C: The Scrum Master would coach the team on improving their estimations and commitment to completing the Sprint Backlog
options.D: The Sprints have failed to produce shippable Increments therefore opportunities to inspect and adapt are lost. The Scrum Master would encourage the organization to add more team members in order to increase the team’s capacity

answers: Inform Peter that the projected completion date is not correct. The Developers would estimate the remaining work to produce a shippable Increment and suggest completing it (make it meet the Definition of Done). Based on empirical data, Peter can adjust the completion date and decide how to continue
explanation: This needs to be communicated with the Product Owner and provide better transparency.

question: Why is it a good practice to include tests in the Definition of Done? (Select the best three answers)

options.A: Because the progress will be easier to show in burndown charts
options.B: Because the results are likely to be releasable
options.C: Because it can simplify requirement definitions
options.D: Because it adds transparency to final Increments

answers: Because the results are likely to be releasable and Because it can simplify requirement definitions and Because it adds transparency to final Increments
explanation: The Scrum Team has a common understanding of what a finished job (Done). With this purpose, we can increase Transparency when there are tests included in the Definition of Done, which will verify how close the work is to being complete and becoming a real Increment usable for final users.

question: Which of the following is the most proper situation during the Sprint Planning considering that we have seven Scrum Teams working in a single product?

options.A: The Product Owner meets only with some representatives from each team to select items from the Product Backlog. Then each representative works with his/her team to create their Sprint Backlog and dependencies are avoided for special escalation Sprints
options.B: All team members meet and together create one Sprint Backlog for the Sprint, in which everyone will work
options.C: Everyone meets at the same place at the same time, Scrum Teams can nominate a smaller number of appropriate people to represent the team on early discussions that are carried out at escalation level, the Product Owner gives information and then every dependency is discussed and coordinated by the teams. Team members can be shifted as needed and Sprint Backlogs for each Scrum Team are created

answers: Everyone meets at the same place at the same time, Scrum Teams can nominate a smaller number of appropriate people to represent the team on early discussions that are carried out at escalation level, the Product Owner gives information and then every dependency is discussed and coordinated by the teams. Team members can be shifted as needed and Sprint Backlogs for each Scrum Team are created
explanation: There should be only one Product Backlog and one Product Owner for one product. Each team needs to have a separate Sprint Backlog. The Developers are responsible for selecting the items from the Product Backlog, however, they can select representatives to do so. They share ownership of these though. Team members can change the composition of teams between Sprints. Even though Product Backlog items should be independent of each other, the dependencies between teams are unavoidable in scaled Scrum and they need to be handled.

question: True or False. Each Sprint Backlog item is owned by one Developer.
answers: No
explanation: All members of the Scrum Team share the accountability of the tasks, not specific Developers. The whole Scrum Team is cross-functional, not a single Developer.

question: When the Developers find themselves in a situation where they don’t have the proper tools and infrastructure, what are the best actions to do? (Select the best two answers)

options.A: A Sprint Zero is created to focus on infrastructure instead of creating an Increment
options.B: The team must create a realistic Definition of Done under current circumstances
options.C: Coach the Developers to improve its skills, tools, and infrastructure over time and adjust the Definition of Done accordingly
options.D: The Developers can’t implement Scrum. They have to use other methods

answers: The team must create a realistic Definition of Done under current circumstances and Coach the Developers to improve its skills, tools, and infrastructure over time and adjust the Definition of Done accordingly
explanation: Sprint Zero does not exist in the Scrum framework and all the Sprints should be able to create an Increment of working software. The Inspections and Adaptation concepts are about making adjustments gradually through the project, this includes infrastructure and tools.

question: True or False. The Sprint Backlog does not contain items pulled only from the Product Backlog.
answers: Yes
explanation: We can’t change the Sprint Goal, however, the team can talk and negotiate with the Product Owner in order to add new Sprint Backlog Items as needed or add non-functional requirements (testing, etc).

question: How should the members of multiple teams be composed for a single project?

options.B: Scrum Master chooses the team members for each team
options.C: Management chooses the team members for each team
options.D: The Product Owner chooses the team members for each team
options.E: Developers themselves will decide the team's composition
options.F: Everyone together will decide on how to form the teams

answers: Developers themselves will decide the team's composition
explanation: Developers should be self-managed and they’re responsible for team formations and composition.

question: True or False. The Product Owner is required to be involved for the sizing of the Product Backlog items.
answers: No
explanation: The Developers who will be doing the work are responsible for the sizing. The Product Owner may influence the Developers by helping them understand and select trade-offs.

question: Stakeholders can participate in this Scrum Event.

options.C: Daily Scrum
options.D: Sprint Planning

answers: Sprint Review and Sprint Planning
explanation: The purpose of the Sprint Review is to inspect the outcome of the Sprint and determine future adaptations. The Scrum Team presents the results of their work to key stakeholders and progress toward the Product Goal is discussed. Stakeholders could also attend Daily Scrum, but only as listeners. In the Sprint Planning the team might invite others to give advice to it could be the Stakeholders.

question: Bill Gates, the CEO of your organization and one of the most important customers, asked some Developers to add a new feature in the middle of the Sprint. What should they do?

options.A: Add the new feature to the Sprint Backlog
options.B: Replace an item in the current Sprint Backlog with the new one
options.C: Reject the request
options.D: Refer them to the Product Owner
options.E: Add the new feature to the Product Backlog

answers: Refer them to the Product Owner
explanation: One of the main responsibilities of the Product Owner is to maximize the value of the Developers' work, and he’s the only one who can add new items to the Product Backlog. Even when the Developers own the Sprint Backlog, the members can’t add items like this, the Product Owner must make sure that any new item adds value and she or he can work with proper stakeholders about it and then add it to the Product Backlog for the next Sprints. Also, the Product Owner can reject the new feature, rather than the Developers.

question: True or False. All the Scrum Artifacts are designed to maximize transparency of key information.
answers: Yes
explanation: Scrum’s artifacts represent work or value. They are designed to maximize transparency of key information. Thus, everyone inspecting them has the same basis for adaptation.

question: During Sprint Planning, the Scrum Team has some doubts about a few items at the top of the Product Backlog. The Product Owner, Angel, tries to contact the customer to talk to them about the meanings of the items, but all the customer representatives are in a meeting and won't be out until two hours after the planned finish of Sprint Planning. What would you advise, as the Scrum Master?

options.A: Cancel the Sprint Planning meeting, give them some time to prepare, and then hold another Sprint Planning
options.B: Extend the duration of Sprint Planning and ask them to discuss the items more and reach agreement
options.C: None of the answers apply
options.D: All answers apply
options.E: Cancel the Sprint and start the next one when the items are clear
options.F: Ask the Developers to come up with their best guess and don’t worry too much about their capacity

answers: Ask the Developers to come up with their best guess and don’t worry too much about their capacity
explanation: Sprint Planning has a timebox that can't change and Scrum events are mandatory, nobody can cancel one of them(Sprint Planning or Sprint). The Developers should go with the best guess, if they need to bring more tickets, they will do it later in the Sprint.

question: What amount of work should the Developers do to a selected Product Backlog item to complete the Sprint?

options.A: As much as needed in adherence to the definition of “Done’
options.B: Requirements analysis, design, implementation, testing, documentation and some maintenance
options.C: All the needed work including some improvements
options.D: As much as they can do in the Sprint

answers: As much as needed in adherence to the definition of “Done’
explanation: The agreed Definition of Done for the Scrum Team, is used to assess when work is complete on the product Increment in order to deliver an Increments of potentially releasable functionality.

question: Which of the following statements are true about Scrum? (Select the best two answers)

options.A: Simple to understand and difficult to master
options.B: Scrum is a methodology for managing complex projects
options.C: Scrum is a framework within which people can address complex adaptive problems
options.D: Sprints maximum length is six weeks

answers: Simple to understand and difficult to master and Scrum is a framework within which people can address complex adaptive problems
explanation: Scrum is not a methodology or body of knowledge, it is a framework that helps people, teams and organizations generate value through adaptive solutions for complex problems.

question: Which of the following statements are true about the Scrum Master? (Select the best three answers)

options.A: Serves the Scrum Team in several ways
options.B: Is responsible for updating the burndown chart
options.C: Is the sole person responsible for managing the Product Backlog
options.D: It’s a management position
options.E: Coaching the Developers in self-management and cross functionality

answers: Serves the Scrum Team in several ways and It’s a management position and Coaching the Developers in self-management and cross functionality
explanation: Despite the Scrum Master not managing people, he manages the processes. That’s why it’s considered management accountability. The Scrum Team is self-managed, the Scrum Master can coach and help but the Developers handle the progress and performance of the Sprints. Finally, It is the Product Owner who owns the Product Backlog.

question: Scaled Scrum is one that conforms to Scrum and uses more than one team for one or more Sprints.
answers: Yes
explanation: Scaled Scrum conforms to Scrum, it's compatible with Scrum. It's called scaled Scrum when there is more than one team. However, it's not necessary to have more than one team in all Sprints, it can be for some of them.

question: When should the Scrum Team hold the Sprint Retrospective meeting?

options.A: At the end of each project
options.B: When the Product Owner and the Scrum Master determine that is needed
options.C: At the end of each Release
options.D: At the end of each Sprint
options.E: At the beginning of each Sprint

answers: At the end of each Sprint
explanation: The Sprint Retrospective occurs always after the Sprint Review and prior to the next Sprint Planning.

question: Which of the following are the best approaches that a Scrum Master could take when a Scrum Team doesn’t have the proper infrastructure to do the work needed to complete the selected Product Backlog items? (Select the best two answers)

options.C: Help the Scrum Team to create proper Sprint Goal and Definition of Done accordingly under current circumstances
options.D: Coach the Developers to improve infrastructure while adjusting the Definition of Done properly
options.E: Create a special Sprint to get infrastructure instead of creating an Increment

answers: Help the Scrum Team to create proper Sprint Goal and Definition of Done accordingly under current circumstances and Coach the Developers to improve infrastructure while adjusting the Definition of Done properly
explanation: The infrastructure and tools are prepared gradually throughout the project, and the Sprint Goal and Definition of Done should be realistic and created accordingly.

question: How much of the Sprint Backlog needs to be defined throughout the Sprint Planning meeting?

options.A: Just enough for the Product Owner to be able to assign tasks to Developers
options.C: All answers apply
options.D: Absolutely all the work
options.E: Just enough to create the baseline for the whole project
options.F: Just enough, so that the Developers can estimate what they can do and to start the work on the first days of the Sprint

answers: Just enough, so that the Developers can estimate what they can do and to start the work on the first days of the Sprint
explanation: Scrum does not do upfront planning, only a few tasks broken down from the items are created in the Sprint Planning. The Developers are self-managed, their members decide who does what and there is no baseline for a Scrum project.

question: The Developers cannot forecast how much work they can do in the upcoming Sprint, because of uncertainties in the Product Backlog that the Product Owner is not able to overcome. What of the following actions should the Scrum Master recommend? (Select the best two answers)

options.A: Ask the Developers to come up with their best guess and do not worry too much about their capacity
options.B: Extend the duration of Sprint Planning and ask them to discuss the items more and get into agreement
options.C: Invite everyone to discuss this problem in the next Sprint Retrospective and try to find a solution
options.D: Cancel the Sprint Planning meeting, give them some time to prepare, and then hold another Sprint Planning
options.E: Cancel the Sprint and start the next one when the items are clear

answers: Ask the Developers to come up with their best guess and do not worry too much about their capacity and Invite everyone to discuss this problem in the next Sprint Retrospective and try to find a solution
explanation: Sprints are canceled when the Sprint Goal becomes obsolete and this can only happen from the PO, not for reasons such as this. What happens is that you will start the next Sprint and the next Sprint Planning right away. Remember, Sprints start one after the other, and we don't do anything outside the Sprints. Sprint Planning is timeboxed, we can't extend it. Developers should pick a number of items (best guess). If it's not enough, you can pick more later. If it's too many, you will just deliver as many as you can. Nothing bad happens if you don't deliver all items in the Sprint Backlog. The goal is to generate value, not to develop all items in the backlog.

question: True or False. The structure of the Daily Scrum is set by the Developers.
answers: Yes
explanation: The Developers own the Daily Scrum meetings, they can be conducted in different ways but always focus on progress toward the Sprint Goal.

question: A Scrum Team found out in the Sprint Retrospective that their main issue is that they do not focus on the most valuable items during their Sprint. What Scrum Values? Which Scrum Values are demonstrated by focusing on the most valuable items first? (Select the best three answers)

options.C: Inspection
options.D: Focus
options.E: Self-management

answers: Respect and Focus and Courage
explanation: The Scrum Values are Commitment, Courage, Focus, Openness, and Respect. Make sure you are not confusing them with the Scrum Pillars (transparency, inspection, and adaptation).

question: The Developers and the Product Owner are not working together at all. What should the Scrum Master do?

options.A: Coach the Product Owner and the Developers about Scrum values and Incremental delivery
options.C: Send everybody to a Scrum capacitation course and restart the project
options.D: Report the Product Owner to her/his manager

answers: Coach the Product Owner and the Developers about Scrum values and Incremental delivery
explanation: The Scrum Master must coach the whole Scrum Team members in organizational environments in which Scrum is not yet fully adopted and understood to practice agility. The Scrum Master must help them to effectively communicate with each other, but be careful, don’t act as a go-between for them.

question: During Sprint Planning, the Product Backlog items are often decomposed into smaller work items. Ideally, how long should these smaller items take to be completed?

options.C: One week or less
options.D: One month or less

answers: One day or less
explanation: For each selected Product Backlog item, the Developers plan the work necessary to create an Increment that meets the Definition of Done. This is often done by decomposing Product Backlog items into smaller work items of one day or less.

question: Who is responsible for getting buy-in from stakeholders?

options.C: The Product Owner
options.D: The Project Manager

answers: The Product Owner
explanation: The Product Owner is responsible for getting buy-in, understanding the stakeholders’ concerns and goals. The Product Owner communicates and represents the desires of the customer.

question: How often should the composition of the team change?

options.A: Every Sprint, to encourage creativity and openness
options.C: As needed, without a need to be concerned about changes in productivity
options.D: As needed, considering that it will have a short-term reduction in productivity

answers: As needed, considering that it will have a short-term reduction in productivity
explanation: In the beginning other team members have to help to bring new members up to speed so a small reduction in productivity is expected.

question: A few members of the Scrum Team discuss work that is not being done. A few Developers support that it is part of the Definition of Done, others say it isn't. What are the best actions for the Scrum Master to take in such a situation?

options.A: Organize a meeting with the people involved aside. Ask them to resolve this outside of the team and maybe involve their line managers
options.B: Remind the Scrum Team of the Scrum Values
options.C: Defuse the prevailing conflict. Teach the Developers how to interpret the Definition of Done. This will help the team to autonomously decide whether the debated work is or is not part of it
options.D: Remind the team that conflicting ideas are natural but making it personal should be avoided
options.E: Decide by yourself if work is part of Definition of Done
options.F: Organize a session and coach the team. Help the entire team resolve the conflict by themselves and create a uniform Definition of Done

answers: Remind the Scrum Team of the Scrum Values and Remind the team that conflicting ideas are natural but making it personal should be avoided
explanation: Conflict is not bad for a team, but members must have respect for each other. Instead of arguing, both the team members must express their point of view and have a constructive discussion. When a Product Backlog item or an Increment is described as “Done”, everyone must have a common understanding of what “Done” means. Although this may vary significantly per Scrum Team, members must have a shared understanding of what it means for work to be complete, to ensure transparency.
